column4: this research program aims to a) understand the impacts of three increasingly popular technologies on women and b) find ways to reduce inappropriate medicalisation and harm."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009432^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009432"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"NextGen evidence synthesis to maximise data utility and improve health outcomes
column2: Investigator Grants"^"To bring together results from different studies
column3: researchers would traditionally extract results from journal articles. Often
column4: not all required information is available in these articles. New methods bring together full datasets of previous studies. This research program will develop these methods
column5: looking at how to 1) best share data and 2) find and exclude fraudulent or low-quality studies. The program will also apply these methods looking at 1) babies born too early and 2) childhood obesity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009447^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009447"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Biomimetic nanoparticles as a gene delivery platform for combinational brain tumour treatment
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Gene engineering shows exciting potential in biomedical applications including cancer therapies. However
column3: effective therapies for brain tumour remain limited due to the cascade brain delivery challenges
column4: which markedly limits their translational potential. This project aims to develop a new treatment strategy for the delivery of state-of-the-art gene therapies directly into the brain
column5: which may provide a new effective and safe therapy for brain tumour patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009464^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009464"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Decoding the drivers of food choices towards sustainable self-management of obesity
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Excessive eating of caloric foods is increasing the number of people who suffer obesity. Available treatments focus too much on personal efforts to reduce eating
column3: and do not pay enough attention to the joint role of mental states
column4: attractive foods and overwhelming marketing. I will use new research tools
column5: such as brain scans taken while eating
column6: mathematical algorithms made to reveal subconscious aspects of behaviour and virtual reality to assist people with obesity to change food choices."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009476^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009476"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Predictive biomarkers of response
column2: resistance and toxicity with immunotherapy in melanoma
column3: Investigator Grants"^"Immunotherapy has activity across many cancers
column4: none more so than melanoma where approximately half the patients with metastatic disease may be cured. Half the patients do not benefit
column5: however
column6: and the drugs can cause toxicity and are expensive. At present
column7: clinicians have little ability to predict who will and will not respond to therapy or get toxicity
column8: nor the mechanisms underlying this. Improving this understanding will improve patient outcomes and reduce costs to the healthcare system."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009504^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009504"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Ribosome biogenesis and disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Ribosomes are macromolecular machines that synthesise all cellular proteins and their catalytic core
column3: the ribosomal RNAs
column4: are synthesised from hundreds of ribosomal genes in a sub-nuclear body termed the nucleolus. This application continues my work on developing drugs that target the nucleolus for cancer therapies and ribosomopathies and investigate new non-ribosomal functions of the nucleolus that we believe are important for normal cellular development and which are dysregulated in disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009507^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009507"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Heat and Health: Building resilience to a warming planet across the human lifespan
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Each year peak temperature records are repeatedly broken around the world. We already know the health effects of extreme heat can be potentially devastating
column3: from pregnancy through to older age. This investigator grant will explore different ways to increase our resilience to a warming world across the entire lifespan in way that is sustainable for the future
column4: protects the most vulnerable
column5: and helps reduce the risk of other diseases that are aggravated by heat stress."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009529^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009529"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Optimising palliative care services to deliver better value health care for older people
column2: Investigator Grants"^"The recent report from the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety in Australia highlighted substandard palliative care in Australiaâs aged care system. This research will transform the way in which palliative care services are delivered for older people by designing and evaluating new approaches to ensure quality palliative and end of life services in the residential and community aged care system."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009548^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009548"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Advancing Australian human challenge trials for priority pathogens
column2: Investigator Grants"^"In human challenge models
column3: healthy volunteers are given a carefully monitored infection
column4: with healthcare support
column5: to learn how diseases work and how to stop them. I built the worldâs only strep throat human model and will use it to test vaccines to stop Strep A diseases
column6: which affect ~1 billion people and kill >500
column7: 000 annually. I will build challenge models for other important diseases (like pneumonia) and work with the public and participants to maximise the impact of this kind of research."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009550^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009550"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Risk and resilience in Alzheimer's pathogenesis
column2: cognitive decline and clinical disease progression
column3: Investigator Grants"^"Alzheimerâs disease is the most common form of dementia
column4: and the number of people living with it will triple by 2050. There is currently no cure for Alzheimerâs disease
column5: and the only means of slow the growing epidemic is to delay onset. My research program aims to identify risk and resilience factors of Alzheimerâs disease. This will uncover novel disease-modifying strategies
column6: improve clinical trial design
column7: and develop algorithms that will predict individualsâ rate of disease progression."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009551^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009551"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Modulating protein-protein interactions in disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Healthy lives are powered by countless interactions between proteins that induce normal body functions. Infections
column3: mutations
column4: physical/chemical damage wear down our immune defences and lead to disease. This program will create new knowledge and approaches to discover new medicines
column5: larger than conventional drugs but smaller than antibodies. They will modulate protein-protein interactions on or in cells to suppress inflammatory/metabolic diseases in rodents
column6: on a path to clinical trials."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009554^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009554"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting Follicular Helper T cells to Boost Protective Humoral Immunity
column2: Investigator Grants"^"After vaccination
column3: the immune system is activated and acquires the ability to secret antibodies that recognise and destroy pathogens. However
column4: vaccines donât always induce sufficient immunity. The interactions between different types of immune cells play an essential role in regulating the generation of high-quality antibody immunity. This research will investigate the mechanisms governing this process. The new knowledge will have broad applications for infection control or vaccine design."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009564^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009564"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Advancing peptide-based drug design
column2: Investigator Grants"^"I will use molecules called peptides to make safer
column3: more effective medicines. These next-generation drugs will have fewer side effects than existing drugs due to their highly specific interactions with their target sites in the body. In the past pharmaceutical companies have not been able to utilise peptides because of technical challenges associated with their synthesis and delivery. My work has led to solutions to these problems that will be exploited to develop new drugs for pain and cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009572^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009572"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel methods for analysing causal pathways to disease in longitudinal studies
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Health research studies obtain increasingly detailed data from participant biosamples that could in principle provide key insights into disease causality. However
column3: the analytical tools and expertise for realising this potential are lacking. This program aims to develop
column4: disseminate and apply novel data analysis methods that address this gap
column5: as well as building biostatistical capacity in this area. Program outcomes will be urgently needed tools
column6: expertise and new knowledge for improving health."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009577^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009577"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Tackling multimorbidity in women across the life course: Building the evidence for improved prevention strategies and care pathways
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Multimorbidity
column3: where a person has two or more chronic conditions
column4: is increasing and is more common among women than men. Women also face different risks for multimorbidity
column5: and some can have conditions that interact and require complex care plans. My research addresses gaps in our understanding of how multimorbidity develops in women and of the corresponding care plans. The new knowledge will inform more personalised and co-ordinated care for prevention and management of multimorbidity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009612^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009612"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving evidence synthesis methods to enhance decision making about public health and policy interventions
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Systematic reviews synthesize available research to determine whether policy
column3: health service delivery
column4: and public health interventions are effective. Statistical methods underpin the validity of the findings in systematic reviews. This research will evaluate and develop statistical methods for systematic reviews with the aim of improving the quality of reviews and ensuring healthcare decisions are based on reliable research syntheses."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009633^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009633"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reducing medication-related harm in people living with dementia in residential aged care
column2: Investigator Grants"^"People who live in aged care facilities
column3: particularly those living with dementia
column4: often take multiple medications and are at increased risk of medication-related harm. My research aims to reduce medication-related harm by addressing key steps in the medication-management cycle where errors and harm can occur. I will work with consumers
column5: aged care providers and health care professionals to ensure my findings are translated into practice to improve quality of life for people living with dementia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009642^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009642"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting skeletal muscle for the treatment of insulin resistance
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Insulin resistance is a condition that leads to high-blood glucose and poor muscle function. It is the fastest growing chronic disease in Australia and the major contributor to type-2 diabetes and sarcopenia. We urgently need new treatment strategies. We have identified a series of novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of insulin resistance. This project will analyse these therapeutic targets in preclinical models and improve our understanding of the molecular events of insulin resistance."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009670^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009670"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving outcomes in advanced lung and gynaecological cancers through innovations in clinical trials
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Lung and ovarian cancers are major causes of cancer-related deaths in Australia and worldwide. Improving outcomes for these cancers is a national priority. The overall aim of this project is to better personalise patient treatment and improve their cancer outcomes. The specific objectives are to develop new therapies and strategies for combination treatment
column3: identify new biomarkers
column4: evaluate benefits and harms from treatments
column5: and improve selection of patients for more appropriate therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009675^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009675"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using clonal multi-omics to better understand haematopoiesis
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Our body must continually produce white blood cells to fight infection. When this production goes wrong it can lead to too few cells (immune deficiency) or too many (leukemia). We will examine this process using cutting edge single cell technologies to trace the developmental origins and pathways of individual cells as they mature. In this way
column3: we will learn how to treat these diseases and inform new ways to boost immunity or treat immune and inflammatory diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009707^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009707"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reconstructing ancestral viruses to fight current and future flavivirus outbreaks
column2: Investigator Grants"^"I am a co-inventor of a powerful toolset combining advanced structural biology and rapid virus engineering that enables the investigation of flavivirus structure and immune response at the molecular level. This project integrates these approaches to resurrect ancient flaviviruses and explore the structural evolution of non-human primate flaviviruses
column3: which will be used to understand viral evolution
column4: improve outbreak preparedness and design safer and more effective vaccines."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009711^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009711"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Driving rational improvement of vaccines against respiratory viruses
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Respiratory viruses
column3: such as influenza and human coronaviruses
column4: impose a significant burden on human health and present major pandemic risks. There is a critical need for highly effective vaccines to protect susceptible human populations. This research program will expand our understanding of fundamental drivers of protective immunity against respiratory viruses and integrate these insights in the design and testing of novel vaccine concepts that produce durable and efficacious immunity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009726^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009726"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reducing sex disparities in stroke through a deeper understanding of risks and management patterns
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Each year
column4: 000 Australians die from one of the biggest killers in Australia and globally
column5: stroke. There is high demand for effective prevention and treatment strategies. However
column6: published evidence suggests that women and men experience the disease and its medical care differently. My research aims to better understand why such differences exist and how to provide sex-specific
column7: strategies to improve survival from stroke."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009727^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009727"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing a community-led coordination and response guide for a syphilis outbreak in Aboriginal communities
column2: Investigator Grants"^"My program of research has two phases. Phase 1 will evaluate the how the World Health Organization establishes and deploying outbreak teams to different countries. Phase 2 aims to 1) evaluate Australia National Notifiable Surveillance System with a focus on the identification of Aboriginal people and alerts for potential outbreaks and 2) to develop a community-based coordination guide for syphilis outbreaks that includes Aboriginal leadership
column3: governance and our biggest strength
column4: our culture."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009730^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009730"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Addressing evidence gaps to improve adolescent the sexual and reproductive health
column2: Investigator Grants"^"My research focuses on identifying opportunities to improve the sexual and reproductive health of adolescents living in Australia and other parts of the world. This involves working with adolescents and health services to co-design and test new strategies to deliver sexual and reproductive health that is specifically focussed on the needs of young people."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009732^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009732"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing a multi-omics platform for the diagnosis of mitochondrial disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Mitochondrial Diseases (MDs) are the most common inherited metabolic disorders. They can be caused by changes in more than 300 different genes and affect any or all of our organ systems. New genomic (DNA) technologies have increased our ability to diagnose MDs from less than a quarter of patients to about a half. DNA is the blueprint for protein. This study seeks to further improve the diagnostic rate by using new âproteomicâ technologies that can detect changes in thousands of proteins at once."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009736^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009736"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Translating precision antibiotic dosing into better outcomes for severe infections
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Millions of people die from infections around the world each year
column3: in part
column4: from inadequate antimicrobial use. Antimicrobial dosing is an aspect of therapy which clinicians can control and improve if given sufficient information. My research program will explore the benefits of using a dose that is optimised for an individual patient
column5: to ensure the patient is cured from that infection
column6: and not contribute to the emergence of antimicrobial resistant bacteria."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009750^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009750"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Macrophage Biology in Health and Disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Macrophages are cells of the innate immune system. They are found in every organ and act as the body's waste disposal system and contribute to repair of damaged tissue. In many diseases
column3: their functions are out of control and they contribute to injury and symptoms. In this project we aim to understand how macrophages are made and controlled and to exploit that knowledge to develop new therapies in regenerative medicine."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009765^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009765"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mitigating the consequence of preeclampsia for mother and child
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Preeclampsia
column3: a condition unique to pregnancy
column4: is a major cause for premature birth
column5: death and disability for both mother and baby. No treatment exists that can control the disease to reduce these risks. This research assesses a promising new therapy derived from broccoli sprouts that could prolong pregnancy
column6: reducing the risk of preterm birth. New approaches to diagnosing preeclampsia earlier and to prevent women from poor health outcomes in the years that follow will also be explored."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009767^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009767"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving assisted reproductive technology outcomes - a personalised approach
column2: Investigator Grants"^"One in seven couples have problems conceiving. Assisted reproductive technology (ART) is the last resort for all couples with prolonged unresolved infertility. There is a lack of personalised evidence-based guidance on choosing the best treatment strategies during ART. I will systematically evaluate the effectiveness and safety of treatment options in multiple steps during ART and provide a personalised treatment pathway to improve ART outcomes in couples with infertility."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009771^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009771"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Addressing Health Inequality Experienced by People with Intellectual Disability
column2: Investigator Grants"^"People with intellectual disability face stark health inequalities
column3: die prematurely from potentially avoidable causes and experience poor access to preventative health care. This project will find out why there are gaps in health care for people with intellectual disability
column4: determine how these gaps affect people and develop better responses in healthcare for people with intellectual disability."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009776^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009776"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Increasing the value of evidence from nutritional epidemiology
column2: Investigator Grants"^"In nutrition research
column3: observational studies are fundamental sources of evidence as it is often impossible or unethical to conduct randomized controlled trials. Unfortunately
column4: many nutritional epidemiological studies fail to provide useful evidence due to poor data analysis methods. My research will improve the quality of evidence from nutritional epidemiology by developing practical solutions to the challenges of dietary data analysis by advancing analysis methods and tools."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009782^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009782"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Lost in translation: Accelerating the implementation of digital interventions in youth mental health
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Mental ill-health affects one in four young Australians. Digital interventions can deliver high-quality accessible mental health care to those in need
column3: however
column4: they currently sit disconnected from our overburdened
column5: antiquated mental health system. My research program will address this historic failure of research translation
column6: by refining
column7: evaluating
column8: and disseminating a blueprint for digital mental health implementation â propelling Australian youth mental health care into the 21st century."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009783^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009783"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Super-Responders and Super-Survivors â how to dramatically improve cancer outcomes
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Ovarian cancer and other rare cancer types have low survival rates. My program will study women who achieve very long remissions (âSuper-Respondersâ) following PARP inhibitor + immune therapy and âSuper-survivorsâ
column3: individuals who develop three or more cancers. The underlying genetic mechanisms for this are poorly understood. By studying both
column4: we expect to discover key molecular and immune pathways that should underpin effective therapies to prevent cancer recurrence."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009798^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009798"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Innovative public health interventions to control the global burden of Strep A disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Strep A causes over 500
column3: 000 deaths in the world each year
column4: especially due to rheumatic heart disease. Scabies is a major driver of Strep A skin infection in our region. I propose to tackle the problem with 2 innovative approaches. First
column5: I will test new vaccines using a human model of Strep A infection and in a large clinical trial. Second
column6: I will investigate how mass treatment for scabies can impact on Strep A skin infection and rheumatic heart disease
column7: and I will test new drugs and diagnostics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009800^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009800"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Innovations in Clinical Trials Research: from personalised medicine to population health
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Well-designed clinical trials including translational research are critical for real advances in healthcare. The proposed research involves major clinical trials evaluating new treatments and strategies in cancer
column3: cardiovascular disease and perinatal medicine; novel methods for better trials; and integrating evidence for better decision-making in healthcare. The aim is to integrate clinical research into routine care and use translational science to optimise treatment for individual patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009808^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009808"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving back pain care in Australia
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Over the next five years
column3: this research program will improve the care provided for back pain in Australia
column4: the number one cause of disability. To accomplish that goal
column5: a series of health policy evaluations at the national and state level
column6: a randomised trial to reduce unnecessary lumbar surgeries and improve return to work
column7: and two studies to investigate barriers and enablers of the right care for back pain will be conducted."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009820^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009820"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide as a novel target for ageing and dementia
column2: Investigator Grants"^"A better understanding of novel molecular targets of disease to use in diagnostics and therapeutics for age-related cognitive impairment and dementia is urgently needed. My research program will test the hypothesis that raising intracellular NAD+ levels can (1) slow down the onset of dementia-related neuropathology; (2) alter dementia biomarker trajectories; and (3) moderate behavioural/cognitive deficits
column3: in established in animal models and humans cohorts."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009840^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009840"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of clinical tests to improve treatment for ovarian cancer patients
column2: Investigator Grants"^"The aim of this program is to improve ovarian cancer survival. In other cancers
column3: tumour tests at diagnosis are used to guide treatment. I will utilise the resources of the international Ovarian Tumour Tissue Analysis (OTTA) consortium
column4: that I lead
column5: to develop tumour tests to determine the best treatment for each patient. This will include; if they should have surgery before chemotherapy
column6: if they need an alternative to the commonly used chemotherapy
column7: and predicting response to new treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009843^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009843"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Tau - A diagnostic and therapeutic target in Alzheimer's Disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Toxic forms of âtauâ protein in the brain are part of the cause of Alzheimerâs disease. This condition is difficult to diagnose
column3: and there are no treatments to stop progression. My research focuses on developing a blood test measuring the levels of toxic tau in patients attending Australian memory clinics. The program will also undertake a world-first clinical trial of an oral drug (SAMe) that targets the tau protein to understand whether this can slow the progression of Alzheimerâs disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009852^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009852"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Lipid trafficking and storage: from cell biology to novel therapies against diseases
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Lipids represent a major class of molecules in life. They are associated with many common human diseases such as obesity
column3: diabetes
column4: heart disease and cancer. A major gap in knowledge is how our cells store and transport important lipids such as cholesterol. This proposal aims to investigate mechanisms governing the storage and trafficking of lipids
column5: and to also apply the new knowledge to developing novel compounds/therapies against cancer and other diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009866^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009866"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Health Risk Assessment of Bushfire Smoke on Children and Pregnancy Outcomes
column2: Investigator Grants"^"This Investigator Grant program will fill the knowledge gaps in whether bushfire smoke have impacts on children and pregnancy outcomes using new technology
column3: novel approaches and big data analyses. The outcomes will result in improved environmental exposure assessment and reduced hazard of bushfire smoke
column4: leading to substantial gains in population and environmental health. Importantly
column5: this work will enhance capacity building and advance the development of bushfire epidemiology."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009873^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009873"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A Global Programme on Epidemiology
column2: Early Detection and Intervention for Children with Cerebral Palsy in Low- and Middle-Income Countries
column3: Investigator Grants"^"Cerebral palsy (CP) is the leading cause of childhood disability with an estimated 50 million people affected globally. However
column4: majority of the children with CP living in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) do not receive timely diagnosis and intervention. I propose a global research programme across Asia
column5: Africa and South America to study the burden
column6: causes and suitable approaches for early detection and intervention for children with CP in LMICs to improve their lives."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009878^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009878"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Personalised medicine to improve outcomes for men with prostate cancer through seamless integration of novel imaging and targeted therapy (theranostics)
column2: Investigator Grants"^"This grant will enable me as a clinician-scientist to improve outcomes for men with prostate cancer
column3: a disease resulting in more than 3000 deaths in Australia annually
column4: by using a technology called theranostics. Theranostics uses radioactive tumour seeking molecules to integrate whole body imaging and a targeted treatment. I will develop clinical trials with global impact and use artificial intelligence image interpretation to better define patient prognosis and select optimal therapy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009885^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009885"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Deciphering the heterogeneity of chronic breathlessness: implications for more personalised management of the symptom
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Chronic breathlessness is a debilitating symptom affecting >300
column3: 000 Australians with chronic
column4: progressive conditions. This innovative program combines epidemiological
column5: basic science and health services research to generate a world-first classification of clinical sub-types of chronic breathlessness. This will provide more personalised symptom management
column6: and ultimately deliver improved health outcomes and independence
column7: and directly inform clinical practice and reduce health service use."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009940^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009940"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Translating oocyte biology discoveries to clinical practice
column2: Investigator Grants"^"I am reproductive biologist studying factors that regulate the intrinsic quality of unfertilised eggs. I have produced and patented the use of unique growth factors produced by the egg that enhance egg quality in women. Bringing together industry and world-leading clinics
column3: I am developing new forms of hormone-free infertility treatment for cancer and infertile patients
column4: which I will apply in widespread clinical practice over the next 5 years."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009957^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009957"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing new therapies targeting innate immune mediated inflammation in neurodegenerative disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Brain diseases such as Parkinsonâs disease and motor neuron disease remain a burden on society with few effective treatments. Recent studies have documented a key role for the immune system and inflammation in accelerating neurodegenerative disease progression. This project will identify new drugs that can tame the inflammation cascade in the brain
column3: to help treat these diseases. It will assist in the progression of these drugs into human clinical trials to ultimately improve patient outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009965^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009965"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Integrating lipidomic
column2: metabolomic and genomic studies to define causal metabolic pathways in cardiometabolic disease: Delivering precision medicine solutions for Australia.
column3: Investigator Grants"^"Our metabolism plays a central role in the development type 2 diabetes
column4: cardiovascular disease
column5: age related dementia and some cancers. We plan to use new technology (genomics and metabolomics) to understand how our genes and environment combine to influence our metabolism and our health. We will use this new information to develop new tests for risk assessment and early detection and develop new treatments to maintain health and to prevent
column6: attenuate or treat these common metabolic diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009982^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009982"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Building a foundation for equitable population-scale genomic medicine
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Genomic technologies
column3: such as whole-genome sequencing
column4: are already transforming our ability to diagnose
column5: predict
column6: and treat many diseases. However
column7: to ensure that genomic medicine is accessible and useful to everyone
column8: we need more powerful tools for analysis
column9: new databases representing all Australian communities
column10: and new approaches to identify targets for therapeutic drugs. My program will develop methods and resources to establish the foundations for equitable population-scale genomic medicine."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009991^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009991"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Role of Gut-Bacteria in Dementia and Implications for Future Nanomedicine
column2: Investigator Grants"^"My research and recent clinical evidence indicate the involvement of gut-bacteria in the early-onset and accelerated progression of dementia in Alzheimer's Disease. This project will investigate the molecular mechanisms for this toxic communication between gut-bacteria and the brain
column3: and develop a nanotechnology-based approach to block this communication. It will open new therapeutic opportunities to control the progression and inhibit the early-onset of dementia in Alzheimerâs Disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009998^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009998"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing the power of diverse data to model population impacts of injury and inform health and social policy
column2: Investigator Grants"^"This investigator grant program will transform thinking about the long-term impacts of injury and the complex interplay between health and social sectors. The program will establish cross-sectoral data platforms with the real-world capacity to fundamentally change how we use data to characterise injury and its impacts. The findings will drive evidence-informed public health and social policy planning and investment to reduce the population impacts of injury."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010008^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010008"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reducing the impact and burden of substance use on mental health
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Substance use and mental health are both major public health issues that commonly occur together. The relationship between them is not well understood. This work will use advanced statistical models to quantify the relationship
column3: predict how much harm substance use is causing to mental health
column4: and identify how much harm could be prevented by better policy. The knowledge gained will inform policies on how to reduce disease burden caused by substance use on mental health in Australia and overseas."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010037^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010037"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the mechanisms that drive cell competition and plasticity in stomach cancer.
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Cancers of the upper digestive tract (stomach) are composed of a diverse mixture of cell types that function differently depending on the stage of cancer progression. Understanding exactly how the different cell types interact with each other to promote cancer growth at various stages of disease (early
column3: intermediate and late-stage) is crucial in order to develop better cancer therapies to extend patient survival."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010051^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010051"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mitigating the impacts of infectious disease emergencies
column2: Investigator Grants"^"While public health and social measures have been central to the COVID-19 response and saved lives
column3: many uncertainties remain as to their optimal use. Governments have been repeatedly required to balance the consequences of an uncontrolled outbreak against the social and economic costs of interventions. Over the next five years
column4: I will use modelling and decision science to support the development of more tailored and adaptive response policies for COVID-19 and inevitable future pandemics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010053^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010053"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Designing and translating novel therapies for diabetes and kidney disease
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Four million individuals die from diabetes each year and half of these are less than 50 years old. Individuals with earlier onset diabetes in Australia and their families are personally impacted by diabetes specific health issues such as kidney disease. During this five year program of research we aim to better understand the factors responsible
column3: and to progress therapies which may reduce diabetes and kidney disease if made available to these individuals including Indigenous Australians."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010055^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010055"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Health workforce investment to incentivise universal health coverage
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Health workers including doctors
column3: nurses and community health workers are crucial to population health and a major driver of healthcare costs. In low- and middle-income nations
column4: there has been little attention to the most effective way to finance and organise health workers despite the large costs in lost health and wasted expenditure caused by investing in ineffective care. This Fellowship will generate economic evidence to drive rational healthcare investment in low- and middle-income nations."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010063^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010063"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving the mental health of trans and gender diverse young people
column2: Investigator Grants"^"The aim of this research program is to improve the mental health of trans and gender diverse (henceforth trans) children and young people. One stream will be dedicated to better understanding the experiences of trans young people where gaps in knowledge still exist. The other stream will focus on the development of novel interventions to improve the mental health of trans children and young people at the individual and family levels."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010064^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010064"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Bridging the clinico-pathological divide: improving neuroimaging analysis and applications in dementia
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Dementias are a group of incurable and fatal disorders caused by progressive deterioration of the brain function. This program will identify the gradual brain changes that cause symptoms of dementia (e.g.
column3: problems with thinking
column4: language
column5: behaviour and everyday skills) to develop. Greater understanding of how the brain changes throughout the disease course will lead to better diagnosis of dementia and contribute to develop medical treatments to stop the progression of the underlying disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010070^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010070"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving outcomes for men with advanced prostate cancer through innovative clinical trials and biomarker development.
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Prostate cancer (PC) is a common disease and the median survival advantage from novel androgen receptor targeted agents for men with castration resistant disease is measured in months and is not cumulative due to underlying cross-resistance. My research program aims to understand the biology of aggressive forms of PC
column3: define new immune and molecular targets and undertake novel biomarker driven clinical trials that will co-develop new combinations and biomarkers for optimal patient selection."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010072^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010072"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"RetinaAGE as a novel biomarker for ageing and cardiovascular risk
column2: Investigator Grants"^"The back of the eye (retina) is a window to our blood vessels and nervous system and can be easily imaged. I have developed and pilot tested an AI algorithm that can accurately predict age using retinal photos. The gap between age predicted by the algorithm and chronological age
column3: known as RetinaAGE
column4: can predict premature death and cardiovascular events. This project will test RetinaAGE in individuals of different ethnicities and translate this AI into a system that will be tested in clinics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010084^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010084"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Molecular and genomic profiling of rogue lymphocytes in autoimmune disease using single-cell genomics
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Autoimmune disease occurs when the immune system turns "rogue" and attacks tissues within the body. The exact cause of human autoimmune diseases are unknown. A major hurdle in autoimmune disease research is identifying the rogue disease-causing immune cells from normal immune cells. I have developed novel technology capable of identifying and characterising rogue immune cells which will advance our understanding of how these cells arise and persist
column3: and help develop more targeted therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010088^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010088"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Tailoring implementation for forgotten populations in chronic disease management
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Using evidence in clinical practice is challenging when the evidence does not describe how the treatment works or include participants from the population of interest. The aim of this fellowship is to extend research evidence by identifying how treatments for chronic conditions work
column3: and whether they apply to under-served populations in Australia. This information will improve the use of evidence in clinical practice and the uptake of evidence-based treatments for forgotten populations."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010091^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010091"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Research generating evidence to optimise pneumococcal disease prevention
column2: Investigator Grants"^"This research program aims to develop an in-depth understanding of various streptococcus pneumoniae (SP) infections that could be serious and even life threatening. Antibiotic resistance and how COVID-19 and influenza could make people vulnerable to SP infections will be two key areas explored. This research is expected to feed directly in to practice and policy relating to pneumococcal disease surveillance and optimizing prevention using vaccinations during COVID-19 pandemic and beyond."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010100^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010100"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing an Oral Nanoformulation for Preventing Cancer Recurrence
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a highly aggressive disease with high recurrence rate following primary treatment. This project aims to develop an oral nanoformulation for preventing TNBC recurrence by reducing systemic copper level. This formulation is based on an advanced nanobiotechnology which is expected to enable primarily localised copper depletion in the intestine and reduce systemic exposure
column3: thereby minimising adverse off-target effects and improving therapeutic outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010110^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010110"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving Outcomes after Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation is a potentially lifesaving support for patients with severe cardiac or respiratory failure
column3: but the underlying evidence base remains limited. Over the last 7 years
column4: i have build leading program of research
column5: which has led to the development of a national ECMO registry and a large RCT of ECMO for cardiac failure. With this fellowship
column6: i will extend this work to generate new high quality knowledge in major evidence gaps
column7: including a new clinical trial."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010124^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010124"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving Neonatal Resuscitation
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Over 5% of all babies worldwide need help breathing in the seconds after birth. Failing to breath kills more than 1 baby every minute. My grant will investigate simple ideas that may make birth safer for the baby
column3: including: understanding how the baby begins breathing air after birth
column4: augmenting the respiratory drive of premature babies to spontaneously breathe after birth
column5: and helping babies breathe before cutting the umbilical cord so that they are still being supported by their mother."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010128^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010128"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving care for low back pain
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Low back pain is the number-one cause of disability worldwide
column3: affecting an estimated 540 million people at any one time. The disease burden due to low back pain has increased by 54% since 1990
column4: threatening the sustainability of health care systems globally. My research will address the growing burden of low back pain by providing new knowledge on the effect of analgesic medicines and on works to improve the research translation of evidence into care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010134^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010134"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Revealing how tolerance checkpoints fail in human autoimmune diseases and how to target therapy
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Prof Goodnow will lead a program of research defining the root cause of human autoimmune diseases and using these discoveries to guide better targetted treatment for these important
column3: chronic diseases. The research employs new single cell genomic technologies to pinpoint the DNA and other molecular abnormalities that allow rare cells within the immune system to escape the bodyâs normal control processes
column4: and instead attack one or other part of the body to cause autoimmunity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010136^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010136"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Preventing stillbirths and improving care after loss
column2: Investigator Grants"^"In Australia
column3: over 2000 families suffer the tragedy of stillbirth each year. By building on my achievements in rapidly translating new research into maternity care
column4: I will lead my outstanding team to reduce stillbirth rates by 20% and reconcile inequities in stillbirth rates by Australia by 2025. I also anticipate a reduction in adverse neonatal outcomes. When stillbirth or neonatal death does occur
column5: my research aims to ensure all women and families receive optimal care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010141^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010141"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding the role of predictive coding in visual processing: from neural circuits to whole brain systems
column2: Investigator Grants"^"The simple act of perceiving an object in the world depends not only on the incoming sensory information
column3: but also on the brainâs predictions about the objectâs likely identity. This research will characterise the neural mechanisms responsible for predictive coding of visual information. I will combine brain imaging and analogous visual tasks in humans and animal models
column4: and apply novel computational methods to reveal a common code for perception in whole brain systems and individual neurons."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010149^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010149"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding complex I assembly for better diagnosis and future treatment
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Almost all cells in the human body need to produce energy so they can survive and grow. This is achieved by tiny generators in the cell called Mitochondria. When Mitochondria are unable to produce the energy the cell needs it dies and this leads to Mitochondrial Disease
column3: which affects 1 in 2000 people. This project aims to understand one of the biggest contributors to Mitochondrial Disease- called Complex I Deficiency. This will lead to better diagnosis of patients and treatments in the future."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010154^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010154"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Gold Electronic Skins for Remote Biodiagnostics
column2: Investigator Grants"^"This interdisciplinary Eng-IT-Med research program aims to develop artificial intelligence-powered soft gold electronic skins for âhealthâ monitoring of living organisms
column3: including cells
column4: tissues
column5: organoids whenever one wants wherever one wants by a wireless smartphone. It is expected that this program will generate groundbreaking knowledge/technologies in remote monitoring of biological systems
column6: deliver translational outcomes in industries and train a large cohort of workforces."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010156^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010156"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Decoding the epigenome of the tumour microenvironment for improved patient outcomes in prostate cancer
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Just as people in big cities rely on a complex infrastructure network for their daily lives
column3: cancer cells depend on the surrounding tumour microenvironment. Studying the behaviour and interactions of the neighbouring cells is crucial to understanding how a tumour develops and progresses. I will scrutinize the molecular information in prostate tumour microenvironment cells to learn how they emerge and function to promote cancer
column4: and to identify new molecular markers to guide treatment decisions."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010203^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010203"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Building heart muscle to treat cardiomyopathies
column2: Investigator Grants"^"Cardiovascular disease is our major societal and economic health burden. Many types of heart disease are due to a lack of functioning heart muscle cells either resulting from the massive loss of these cells following a heart attack or to the toxic effects of certain drugs in adults
column3: or to inadequate heart growth in children; causing heart failure or death. This study aims to stimulate heart muscle cells to divide
column4: thereby building heart muscle to improve heart function
column5: well-being and survival."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010212^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010212"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Behavioural and social science to close gaps in vaccination coverage
column2: Investigator Grants"^"COVID-19 has cost trillions in economic loss globally and devastated entire nations. The pandemic now has the capacity to be much better controlled with vaccination. But the best vaccines - those against COVID-19 and other diseases - are of no use if the public will not
column3: or cannot
column4: take them. This research will help countries to gather a better understanding of why people don't vaccinate and what to do about it."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2000367^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2000367"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Combination immune therapy for type 1 diabetes
column2: Clinical Trials and Cohort Studies Grants"^"This clinical trial will test whether a combination of two safe therapies
column3: abatacept and nasal insulin
column4: can stop the immune attack that causes type 1 diabetes. Sixty-two children and young adults with recently-diagnosed type 1 diabetes will receive either abatacept and nasal insulin or abatacept and nasal placebo for one year to determine if combined immune therapy preserves pancreas function and decreases the need for insulin therapy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009677^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009677"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mining the host-pathogen interface to deliver a drug pipeline for treating intractable and emerging infections
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Emerging viruses and antibiotic-resistant superbugs are the most important challenge to human health in the 21st century. New viruses such as SARS-CoV2 and Zika
column3: as well as antibiotic resistant superbugs
column4: emerge regularly and rapidly
column5: urgently requiring new therapies. Our multidisciplinary Synergy team has demonstrated success in drug development and will create new drugs to avert the imminent global health disaster posed by emerging viruses and superbugs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009851^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009851"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Linking clinical and basic science discovery to find new treatments for alcohol use disorder
column2: Synergy Grants"^"More than a million Australians meet criteria for an alcohol use disorder
column3: making it a leading cause of death
column4: injury and many diseases. Current treatment is often ineffective and research receives limited attention with no new medications in 20 years. We will create a program for treatment development. We will test new medications and new behavioural treatment in experimental animals before moving to human trials. The approach links outstanding basic science and clinical research groups."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009923^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2009923"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Roadmap Options for Melanoma Screening in Australia (Melanoma-ROSA)
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Melanoma is Australiaâs third most common cancer and the earlier a melanoma is diagnosed the better the patient outcomes. Our program will co-design with consumers a blueprint for a NEW nationwide strategy for effective melanoma screening to inform practice and policy. We anticipate our program will generate evidence that will translate into a targeted melanoma screening program that is equitable in its reach
column3: trustworthy for patients and clinicians
column4: and cost-effective to the system."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010268^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010268"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Tackling Australiaâs low screening participation to prevent bowel cancer morbidity and deaths
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Fifteen years after rollout
column3: participation in our national bowel cancer screening program continues to lag behind comparable programs globally. We have not yet cracked even 50% participation despite the programâs world class free postal test kit and national registry. Current methods at getting people to screen are not working for most people. We content this due to failure to assess novel interventions in randomised controlled trials within the NBCSP."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010275^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010275"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving outcomes for lung cancer patients: Discovering targetable vulnerabilities in lung cancer
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality. One major hurdle faced in the clinic is that many patients fail to respond to currently available anti-cancer drugs. We will leverage the expertise of a diverse team of scientists and clinicians to tease apart the processes that can cause lung cancer to become refractory to current treatments. The discoveries made in this proposal will catalyse translational programs that will lead to improved ways to detect and treat lung cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010287^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010287"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the role and therapeutic manipulation of the gut-lung axis in respiratory disease
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Emphysema is an enormous clinical issue that needs effective treatment. Gut diseases cause lung inflammation. We show that gut bacteria (the microbiome) are altered and can be modified with targeted dietary interventions. We will define these changes and rapidly screen new diet for effectiveness in the lab and then test the most effective in clinical trials in patients. We will define how the new therapies work and progress new interventions to human treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010290^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010290"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Interventions for better life-time mental health outcomes for young Australians with disability
column2: Synergy Grants"^"This research program brings together academic researchers from multiple disciplines to address the entrenched social
column3: economic and mental health disadvantage experienced by Australian youth with disability. In partnership with advocacy groups and government
column4: we will generate new evidence about interventions
column5: including policy reforms
column6: that can reduce the gap in mental health and wellbeing between young people with disability and their non-disabled peers."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010562^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010562"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^""Integrative-omics" for precision medicine in the epilepsies
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Epilepsy affects 4% of the population
column3: with an estimated annual cost of $12.3 billion in Australia in 2019. This is largely due to devastating epilepsies known as Developmental and Epileptic Encephalopathies (DEEs). Patients have uncontrolled seizures
column4: developmental impairment and a high risk of early death. We will bring computational expertise to integrate multiple biological measurements from patients with DEEs to reveal underlying disease dynamics and target new treatment approaches."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010716^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010716"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"STopping Acute Rheumatic Fever Infections to Strengthen Health (STARFISH)
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) is a serious disease caused by preventable Strep A infections
column3: disproportionately affecting Indigenous Australians. Knowledge gaps remain on how to eliminate RHD
column4: and preventing acute rheumatic fever (ARF
column5: the step before RHD) is key. In a global first STARFISH brings together a diverse team of experts to tackle the root causes â social determinants â providing evidence as to how environmental health and housing interventions can stop Strep A spread and prevent ARF."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010736^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010736"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Cerebral Palsy SYNERGY Network to Protect
column2: Repair and improve Outcomes
column3: Synergy Grants"^"Cerebral Palsy (CP) is a life-long condition that affects movement and learning due to early brain injury. Recent research has reduced the number of infants being born with CP by 30 percent and now 70 percent of children will now walk. Our CP Synergy Network will develop new early tests to detect CP
column4: treatments to prevent CP and repair and rehabilitate those with early brain injury that leads to Cerebral Palsy guided by a national consumer network and a diverse multidisciplinary clinical team."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010766^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010766"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"SERPICO Stroke: Synergistic Enhancement of Research design with Precision analytics to Improve Clinical Outcomes in Stroke.
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Our Stroke synergy brings a diverse and revitalised cross-disciplinary team to harness our data infrastructure and pursue a whole new research direction for stroke. We will conduct a suite of new clinical trials with advanced statistical designs to improve trial efficiency. We will also develop completely new brain function and physical frailty measures to predict stroke outcome with embed cost-effectiveness analysis across all our activities to identify new ways to help patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010849^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010849"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Rational design of novel CARs for safe and effective brain cancer immunotherapy
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Glioblastoma is a deadly brain cancer with <5% survival
column3: 5 years after diagnosis. There are no curative treatments so novel approaches are urgently required. This project will improve therapy options for brain cancer by using immunotherapy
column4: an approach showing great clinical promise. Using genetically engineered blood cells designed to specifically kill cancer cells
column5: this project will use cutting edge technology to make new cell therapies and test them in preclinical models of brain cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011100^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011100"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving patient outcomes through implementation of digital and diagnostic innovations for infections in cancer
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Fever and sepsis complicate the management of cancer and occur in up to 90% of patients receiving treatment for certain types of cancer
column3: and in some cases infection is the leading cause of early mortality. Gaps in the management of infection in cancer include lack of access to diagnostic tests and specialist care. This project will incorporate new technologies to deliver life saving care pathways for these vulnerable patients on a national scale."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011139^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011139"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding and averting blood cancer resistance to therapy
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Blood cancers account for one-sixth of all cancer deaths. To substantially reduce this we need to establish why current treatments
column3: including new targeted and immune therapies
column4: fail. We are bringing together experts in different areas of science (biology
column5: bioinformatics
column6: imaging
column7: immunology) and medicine (molecular diagnosis
column8: treatment) to dissect why leukaemias and lymphomas become resistant to new therapies and design strategies to either prevent resistance occurring or to overcome it."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011204^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011204"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"IMPACT: IMplementation of x-ray PhAse-Contrast Tomography to transform cancer diagnosis
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Techniques used for breast and lung cancer imaging miss 20-40% of cancers and use unnecessary radiation. We will clinically implement a novel technique called propagation-based phase-contrast computed tomography (PB-CT) which will exploit X-ray refraction in addition to X-ray absorption. PB-CT increases image signal
column3: offering significantly improved cancer detection and reduced radiation dose. This work will transform cancer diagnosis in Australia and internationally."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011277^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011277"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Respecting the Gift - Empowering Indigenous Communities in Genomic Medicine
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Genomic medicine represents a step change in medical sciences. Yet Indigenous Australians are not represented in
column3: engaged with
column4: nor have equitable access to the benefits of genomic research. Our national consortium will build Indigenous leadership in genomics through Empowering Communities; data sciences; understanding genomic variation; uncovering multi-omic signatures of disease; and translate these findings to health care
column5: ensuring Indigenous peoples can lead genomic research on their terms."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011329^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011329"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"National Precision Health Research Translation for Breast and Prostate Cancer Prevention and Early Detection
column2: Synergy Grants"^"This program will make the next benchmark advance in saving lives from breast and prostate cancer by i) expanding our understanding of the genomic risk factors and improving individualised risk prediction
column3: ii) extending our understanding of Australian attitudes
