column4: views and preferences on returning clinically actionable genomic information and iii) enabling an informed pilot study to demonstrate the feasibility of population genomic testing in the Australian setting."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010310^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010310"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Impaired mucociliary clearance drives Bronchiectasis progression
column2: Ideas Grants"^"How bronchiectasis develops and progresses in the lung remains a mystery. One of the key features of bronchiectasis is the inability to clear mucus from the airways which leads to mucus stagnation. We have a identified a defect in production of the cells critical to moving mucus in the airways in samples taken from patients with bronchiectasis. By identifying the causes of this defect we may be able to reverse it and restore healthy mucus clearance in patients that suffer with bronchiectasis."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010319^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010319"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"OPN as an Immune Checkpoint in KRAS Mutant Colorectal Cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bowel cancer is a very common disease that will be diagnosed in 1/12 Australians living to age 85 and leads to over 4000 deaths annually. Subgrouping of colorectal cancers based on gene changes can predict response to therapy. Our research project specifically focuses on bowel cancers with a KRAS mutation that are usually resistant to currently available therapies. We are using cutting edge technology to identify novel approaches to therapy that will improve outcomes for these patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010330^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010330"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"SPARC as a key regulator of breast cancer metastasis and resistance to therapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"` The extracellular matrix or 'matrix' surrounds all cells and is very important in regulating cell behaviour. In cancer
column3: the matrix is dramatically altered
column4: typically making the cancer more aggressive. We recently developed new ways to study the matrix in breast cancer and in particular during cancer cell spread to other organs. We have uncovered exciting new matrix targets associated with breast cancer metastasis
column5: and this project will validate their potential as novel therapeutic targets."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010332^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010332"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Programmable correction of mitochondrial DNA mutations
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mitochondrial diseases (MD) may occur at any age
column3: affect any body organ
column4: and may result in severe disability and often death. The prognosis for children with mitochondrial disease is especially grim and devastating for families. There are no known cures and it is not possible to predict the future of a child with mitochondrial disease. We have created unique RNA editing tools that can reverse mutations in cells and potentially improve energy metabolism in patient and in vivo models of MD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010336^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010336"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Preclinical evaluation of a streptococcal peptide based specific diagnostic for rheumatic fever and the identification of proteins responsible for the pathogenesis of rheumatic heart disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) is the commonest heart disease in children and young adults. While efforts have been made to control Strep infections that lead to RHD they are ineffective as NO SPECIFIC TEST for timely diagnosis is available. We have identified immune antibodies produced in RHD that can help the development of a new cost effective SPECIFIC test. During this project we will also identify the pathways that lead to heart damage and train and mentor three Indigenous Research Cadets."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010382^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010382"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Machine learning models for personalised epilepsy management
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We will use clinical and genetic information to develop machine learning models to help clinician to select the most effective drug for individual epilepsy patients
column3: and to identify patients likely has drug-resistant epilepsy at the time of diagnosis. These models will be validated in a new multicentre cohort of patients with newly diagnosed epilepsy in Australia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010384^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010384"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Changing the paradigm to improve outcomes for Aboriginal children in out-of-home care
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The evidence is clear that increasing the fit between service provision (research
column3: policy
column4: practice and resources)
column5: and the culture
column6: values and needs of Aboriginal families and children is key to improving health and wellbeing outcomes. Building on the solid foundation of our previous work
column7: this project will change the paradigm and co-design a personalised intervention support program to improve the health and wellbeing outcomes for Aboriginal children in out-of-home care and their families."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010390^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010390"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dual-function ribonucleases: unexpected agents of antibiotic resistance
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bacterial pathogens use a group of enzymes called metallo-Ã-lactamases (or MBLs) that enable them to be multi-drug resistant. Our project aims to determine how MBLs have evolved from harmless and widespread ribonucleases
column3: both deep in the past and potentially very recently in response to modern use of antibiotics. These insights will provide valuable functional and structural information that will enable the development of urgently needed strategies to combat Ã-lactam antibiotic resistance."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010400^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010400"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing structural insights to block pneumococcal manganese uptake
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Streptococcus pneumoniae is the worldâs foremost bacterial pathogen. In Australia
column3: bacterial infections are responsible for more than 9
column4: 000 deaths every year
column5: and the economic burden associated with treating diseases due to S. pneumoniae infections is more than $1 billion annually. This proposal aims to define how manganese
column6: an essential trace element
column7: is scavenged by S. pneumoniae during infection and then use a novel antimicrobial therapeutic strategy to block this pathway and prevent disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010405^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010405"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Genotype Imputation Resources for Productive Genetic Disease Studies of Indigenous Oceanic Sub-Populations
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Indigenous Oceanic sup-populations are perhaps the least-represented of any population in genetic studies. We are proposing productive applications to conduct genetic disease studies by deploying the Indigenous Oceanic genetic analysis resources to promote complex genetic disease studies in these sub-populations. The outcomes will lead to improved disease diagnosis
column3: interventions
column4: treatments
column5: and understanding the interplay of genetic and environmental factors in diseases of IO sub-populations."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010464^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010464"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The role of Piezo1 and TRPM4 ion channels in pathophysiology of cardiac mechano-electric coupling
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Heart hypertrophy is an important risk factor for premature death from a heart disease. In this project we propose to study a new cellular signalling pathway causing heart hypertrophy due to systemic increase in blood pressure. The biological molecules central to this new cellular pathway are the Piezo1 and TRPM4 ion channels underlying contractions of the heart muscle. This project aims to establish a novel paradigm in our understanding of the molecular origins of heart hypertrophy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010522^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010522"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using renewal theory to develop personalised classification and treatment for atrial fibrillation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Atrial fibrillation is the most common disorder of heart rhythm in the Australian community. It is characterised by disordered electrical waves
column3: and mini-tornadoes of electricity called rotors. We have recently developed equations which can accurately predict the number and population distribution of rotors. Here
column4: we will harness this discovery to perform a combination of clinical
column5: experimental
column6: simulation and technology development projects to develop personalised approaches to AF treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010530^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010530"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Prediction of preterm birth using vaginal microbiology
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Recently
column3: our team developed a vaginal microbial DNA test that successfully predicted up to 45% of spontaneous preterm birth (sPTB) cases in mid-gestation pregnant women
column4: the majority of whom were Caucasian (75%). Our next steps are to maximise the testsâ ability to predict sPTB in Aboriginal women
column5: whose vaginal microbiology differs
column6: and to use pre-pregnancy vaginal microbiology to predict sPTB risk in all Australian women prior to conception."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010532^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010532"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A new model of Ã-Spectrin function: understanding how the skin protects neurons from damage
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The spectrin cytoskeleton is thought to function like a spring within neurons to allow them to bend and stretch â protecting them from damage induced by mechanical stress. Human mutations in spectrins cause severe neurological disorders with debilitating symptoms. We propose that spectrins function in tissue surrounding neurons to protect them from damage
column3: and not within them as previously thought. This could revolutionise our understanding of disorders associated with spectrin dysfunction."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010551^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010551"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Resolving prostate cancer health disparities through population-scale genomic interrogation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Geography (environment) and ethnicity (genetics) are significant predictors of prostate cancer (PCa) mortality
column3: specifically Africa or African ancestry. This project harnesses the power of whole genome interrogation and an intercontinental (Australia and Africa) and interethnic (European
column4: African and Asian) study design
column5: to distinguish the genetic and non-genetic factors contributing to PCa disparities. The hypothesis
column6: non-genetic forces leave a âhallmark of DNA damageâ in the evolving tumour."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010571^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010571"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Heterochromatin instability as a molecular driver of haematopoietic ageing
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Ageing of the blood and immune system leaves elderly people more susceptible to infections and blood cancers. Given our ageing population
column3: strategies that can either rejuvenate or slow this process are urgently needed. We have identified an epigenetic pathway that controls blood system ageing. This proposal will provide a comprehensive understanding of this epigenetic pathway in blood system ageing
column4: and determine whether activating this pathway can slow-down or reverse the ageing process."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010593^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010593"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Preparing Australia for the next pandemic: Managing controversy; promoting trust.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project addresses the question: how can we better prepare our institutions and Australian society for the next pandemic? COVID-19 has been characterised by uncertainties about transmission risks and the effectiveness of precautionary strategies
column3: undermining confidence in experts and authorities. This project will develop guidance and practical resources to improve social preparedness for the next pandemic
column4: and promote greater trust within and between expert groups and the broader community."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010600^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010600"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting Renal Energy Metabolism in Kidney Injury and Disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Short-term acute kidney injury and permanent chronic kidney disease affects 1 in 10 Australians. It is unknown how these diseases are interlinked and related to obesity. A lack of energy supply in kidney cells could be the shared link and we will test this theory by targeting energy proteins in the kidney with a new drug O304. We anticipate knowledge generated by our innovative project will catalyse the development of new targeted treatments to improve kidney patient care and quality of life."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010610^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010610"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New approaches to cancer treatment through mRNA display
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This proposal will pioneer the development of a new class of molecules that will block the activity of proteins that regulate gene expression and have been shown to be promising targets for a range of diseases
column3: predominantly cancer. These molecules have the potential to be much more selective and potent than existing molecules and to also open up new directions for cancer therapy by allowing previously intractable molecular targets to be addressed."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010611^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010611"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A gene-editing strategy for telomere-related bone marrow failure
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A subset of inherited bone marrow failure (BMF) syndromes is caused by mutations in genes that protect the ends of chromosomes
column3: or telomeres. The only curative therapy for BMF is bone marrow transplant
column4: which has a high rate of mortality and complications. We will use the latest developments in gene editing of bone marrow stem cells to develop a strategy for correcting mutations in telomere-related genes in the patientâs own cells
column5: providing a potentially curative therapy for inherited BMF."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010632^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010632"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel Hormone Analogues as an Innovative Endocrinological Intervention for the Anaemia of Chronic Disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Anaemia of chronic disease (ACD) is a severe cause of morbidity &amp; mortality in millions of people with cancer or inflammatory diseases. ACD is due to excessive levels of hepcidin
column3: a hormone that prevents gut iron uptake
column4: which inhibits the use of iron for making red blood cells. Thus
column5: excessive hepcidin leads to debilitating anaemia. This proposal will develop innovative Null Hepcidin Analogues that have no hormonal activity
column6: but lead to excretion of excessive hepcidin
column7: thereby curing the anaemia"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010647^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010647"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Alternative splicing: A novel target to improve outcomes in acute myeloid leukaemia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In 2013
column3: we made a breakthrough discovery that certain parts of genes
column4: previously considered âJunk DNAâ
column5: are actually carrying signals to control the amount of proteins produced in cells. Our preliminary work now suggests these signals controlling protein levels can be faulty in cancers. Here
column6: we wish to determine if these faulty signals could be exploited to better manage a deadly blood cancer called acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). Our work will spur the development of novel therapy for AML."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010654^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010654"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Building an Evidence-Base to inform Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) Treatment for Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Communities
column2: Ideas Grants"^"How someone appraises trauma and deals with emotion is core to treating posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Yet these treatments are based on research emphasising Western values. There is an urgent need to examine what appraisals and emotion regulation should be targeted in PTSD treatments for trauma survivors from other cultural backgrounds. This research examines cultural influences on appraisals and emotion regulation in PTSD to improve treatment outcomes for culturally diverse Australians."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010701^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010701"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Driving quality in delirium care through a patient-centred monitoring system in palliative care
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Delirium - sudden confusion and difficulty thinking related to illness
column3: injury or medical treatment - is serious
column4: distressing
column5: and often not addressed for people in hospital at end of life. We will develop and test a new way to monitor delirium in palliative care that involves patients
column6: their family
column7: and staff. The system will align with national quality initiatives
column8: tackle a complex and long-standing clinical issue
column9: and be a key step forward for global quality improvement in palliative care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010704^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010704"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Epithelial mechanics and the fate of cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Many common cancers originate in epithelial tissues
column3: such as the breast
column4: lung
column5: colon and skin. All such cancers first begin as one cancer (transformed) cell within its epithelial tissue of origin
column6: and these can be potentially eliminated by the epithelium to protect against cancer. This research proposal tests how abnormal function of the host epithelium can increase the risk of a newly-transformed cell being retained in the body to progress into a clinically significant tumor."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010711^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010711"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Modelling intellectual disability caused by mutations in chromatin-modifying enzymes to develop ameliorating treatments
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Intellectual disability is a condition that affects speech
column3: motor-coordination and emotional interactions. In cases where it is caused by a reduction in enzyme activity
column4: it may be possible to improve patient outcome by providing more substrate for the enzymatic reaction or by inhibiting the opposing enzymatic activity. We propose to model human genetic disorders in mice to study new treatment options."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010717^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010717"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Global analysis of metabolic targets in Leishmania parasites
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There is an urgent need to develop new drugs to treat human leishmaniasis
column3: a disease that causes debilitating and life-threatening diseases in millions of people worldwide. This project will systematically investigate the function of all metabolic enzymes in Leishmania pathogens using newly developed genetic and analytical tools. The findings of this study will be used to triage Leishmania metabolic enzymes for drug development
column4: with the view of generating more effective anti-parasitics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010743^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010743"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Immune mechanisms underpinning remission of allergy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There is no cure for food allergy. Treatments in development have been shown to induce remission of allergy. This can be transient or long-lasting. We will employ state-of-the-art approaches to characterise the immune changes underpinning remission
column3: particularly whether remission is persistent (long-lasting) or transient. This knowledge would enable the development of more effective long-term treatments for food allergy by providing new targets for intervention
column4: possibly offering a cure."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010757^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010757"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"COVID-19-induced vascular complications: mechanisms and potential therapies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 is responsible for the disease COVID-19
column3: which causes significant lung dysfunction. Importantly
column4: reports have observed COVID-19 symptoms that are not associated with the lungs
column5: such as blood clots
column6: vessel inflammation and leakage of fluid from vessels into tissues. These virus-induced vessel defects can lead to the death of patients. Here
column7: we aim to understand exactly how these vessel defects occur to develop treatments for patients with acute and long term disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010763^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010763"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Brain injury in intimate partner violence: Insight into a silent pandemic
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Intimate partner violence (IPV) is a worldwide problem that primarily affects women. Although &gt;90% of IPV survivors report symptoms consistent with traumatic brain injury (mTBI)
column3: how IPV-related TBI contributes to the lived experience of IPV victims has been remarkably understudied. This translational project will characterise the effects of IPV-related TBI. By doing this
column4: we will be able to development interventions
column5: and change practice and policy
column6: to improvement the well-being of IPV victims."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010778^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010778"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Are nicotine replacement therapy and varenicline safe and effective for women trying to quit smoking during pregnancy?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will measure the safety and effectiveness of two quit smoking medicines during pregnancy. It will use routinely collected data from Australia
column3: New Zealand and the Nordic countries
column4: for over 400
column5: 000 women who smoked during pregnancy. Women who used nicotine replacement therapy or varenicline during pregnancy will be compared to women who smoked but did not use these medicines in relation to quitting and adverse birth outcomes and neurodevelopmental problems among their children."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010781^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010781"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Engineering of novel insulin analogues for improved management of diabetes
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Diabetes is a major global health condition affecting nearly 0.5 billion people. Insulin is an essential treatment for Type 1 and
column3: increasingly
column4: Type 2 diabetes. However
column5: it is difficult to both manufacture and handle as it aggregates rapidly in solution making storage and accurate dosing difficult. We will develop novel modified insulins that are biologically active
column6: long-acting
column7: aggregate-free and which self-respond to increases in glucose levels therefore greatly improving diabetes therapy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010784^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010784"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mapping B-cell fate to improve humoral immunity to malaria
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Malaria killed half a million people in 2019. While ~60 vaccines exist against viral or bacterial diseases
column3: no effective vaccines exist against malaria-causing parasites. Immunity to malaria can be mediated by antibodies. This depends on immune cells called B- and T-cells
column4: conducting a choreographed series of interactions in immune organs. This process appears defective in malaria for reasons unknown. We will determine these reasons
column5: and provide new ways for boosting immunity to malaria."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010795^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010795"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Oncofetal ecosystem in advanced Hepatocellular Carcinoma: Implications for Identifying Immunotherapy response
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Each year ~1800 Australians succumb to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The lack of effective treatment options is a major contributing factor to the poor outcomes. A new immunotherapy treatment which activates the body's immune system
column3: has demonstrated significant efficacy. However
column4: this treatment does not work for all patients. Therefore
column5: we will identify which patients will benefit from this treatment and provide biomarkers
column6: with the overall purpose of guiding clinical decision making."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010804^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010804"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Measuring healthy ageing: finding an autophagy biomarker for a scalable clinical test
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The cells of our bodies possess a powerful recycling system that removes damaged material that accumulates with age and causes diseases such as dementia and atherosclerosis. Although scientists know how to increase this recycling system in laboratory models
column3: we cannot easily measure this function in humans. This study aims to develop easy methods to measure cell recycling in humans so that we can increase the activity of this recycling system to support healthy ageing."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010812^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010812"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mechanisms underlying cortical hyperexcitability in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The current research grant will use novel neurophysiological tools to study brain activity in patients with motor neuron disease/amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. We anticipate that excessive brain activity
column3: called cortical hyperexcitability
column4: will be caused by reduction in activity of cortical inhibitory nerves
column5: increase in activity of cortical excitatory nerves and increase in persistent sodium currents. Treatments
column6: targeting the abnormal brain processes
column7: are likely to be developed."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010813^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010813"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Metabolic and molecular protection against mtDNA mutations
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mitochondria are powerhouses of the cell. Their assembly and function are encoded by a small mitochondrial genome. Mutations in the mitochondrial genome can cause devastating metabolic disorders and have been linked to many common age-related diseases. This project will reveal how cells invoke protective measures to overcome these mutations
column3: thus revealing new mechanisms that can be exploited to combat mitochondria-associated disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010841^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010841"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Coxiella pathogenesis and Effector-Effector Interplay
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Coxiella causes the human infection Q fever. Coxiella has a cohort of virulence proteins that interfere with the human cell. This research will uncover how these proteins function
column3: and interact with each other
column4: to cause disease. This will contribute important new knowledge of pathogenesis that will highlight novel intervention targets. We will also learn how these virulence proteins manipulate human cell functions which are involved in a range of human diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010899^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010899"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Neuropharmacology of decision-making: causal brain network modelling across species
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Decision making is a critical aspect of human cognition that is frequently impaired in clinical disorders. This project will identify the fundamental brain processes governing decision making by studying both monkeys and humans while they perform the same cognitive task. We will identify the critical brain networks that allow organisms to efficiently make decisions and the chemicals which modulate these networks. Our knowledge will inform treatment of clinical disorders of decision making."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010901^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010901"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigating myristic acid as key mediator of memory via myristoylation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Despite the fact the that human brain is made of nearly 60 percent fat
column3: the vast majority of studies on the mechanism of memory and neurodegeneration primarily focused on protein and genetic changes. Here
column4: we discovered that myristic acid production derived from brain cell phospholipids correlates with memory acquisition. Using state-of-the-art mass spectrometry and super-resolution microscopy
column5: we will establish the role of myristic acid in learning and how it is affected during ageing."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010917^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010917"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting neuropilin in SARS-Cov-2 neuronal uptake and transport
column2: Ideas Grants"^"COVID-19 is associated with a variety of neurological symptoms
column3: ranging from a transient loss of smell and taste to headaches to severe ischaemic damage in fatal cases. The long-term consequences of potential interactions of the causative virus
column4: SARS-CoV-2
column5: with brain cells are currently unknown but could be linked to intractable neuronal degeneration as previously found with the 1918 influenza pandemic. We will investigate the uptake and transport of the virus and find ways to block infection."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010919^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010919"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Detecting Referable Glaucoma Using Artificial Intelligence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness worldwide affecting over 300
column3: 000 Australians. While treatments are available to delay vision loss
column4: no cure for glaucoma exists
column5: making early identification of at-risk individuals an utmost priority. We have developed a model that can accurately detect early glaucoma-specific changes in the eye. In this project
column6: we will evaluate the performance of our model in comparison to assessments made by glaucoma specialists to determine its efficacy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010939^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010939"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Molecular mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of complex I dysfunction and mitochondrial disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mitochondria are the powerhouses of our cells that produce the chemical ATP for functions such as muscle contraction and triggering of nerves. Mitochondrial Complex I is a molecular motor that helps to make this ATP and defects in this motor cause mitochondrial disease
column3: resulting in early childhood death. In this project we will study how Complex I is assembled and determine how defects in this assembly pathway leads to disease. New insights into therapeutic approaches will be investigated."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010955^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010955"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigating complement C5a receptor 2 as a therapeutic target for diabetic kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Kidney disease is a serious and common complication of diabetes and the leading cause of kidney failure worldwide. We have found that the complement system
column3: which is a normal part of the immune system
column4: is overactivated in diabetes and leads to kidney injury. We propose studies to not only understand how complement leads to kidney disease in diabetes
column5: but also to identify novel therapeutic targets to enable the development of new treatments for diabetic kidney disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010979^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010979"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel antibody-based treatment for polymicrobial sepsis.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Sepsis or blood poisoning kills more than 7000 Australians every year and there is no cure for this disease. Using the CRISPR gene editing technology
column3: we identified and characterized the receptor protein responsible death during sepsis in mice. We also have developed antibodies against the human counterparts of this receptor. We propose to test these antibodies in mice and human sepsis patients. We also propose to test a diagnostic marker for sepsis-associated mortality in sepsis patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010992^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010992"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting a novel epigenetic regulator of Hodgkin lymphoma
column2: H2A.B
column3: for treament of cancer
column4: Ideas Grants"^"We have identified a novel key regulator of Hodgkin Lymphoma
column5: epigenetic factor
column6: histone H2A.B. This proposal aims to develop novel therapeutic tools that would target H2A.B and potentially provide a more specific and less toxic treatment for Hodgkin Lymphoma patients. We will use Modular Nanotransporters
column7: a highly specific intracellular delivery system
column8: to target H2A.B for degradation and we will use the small molecule kinase inhibitors for functional inactivation of H2A.B."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010998^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010998"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting metabolism to improve healthy ageing
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Ageing is the largest risk factor for chronic diseases that account for most of the financial burden of disease and 90% of deaths in Australia. The goal of this project is to test a new small molecule drug in mouse models of ageing to test the hypothesis that it will improve healthy ageing by decreasing age-related organ deterioration. Success of this project would provide support for clinical translation that could benefit individuals and society by decreasing disease incidence."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011004^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011004"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting caloric efficiency to treat obesity-related diabetes
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Diabetes is a major unmet medical need in Australia. We have recently discovered a new class of drug that reverses obesity and pre-diabetes in mice. The objectives of this project are to determine whether this drug is effective in a mouse model of very severe obesity-related diabetes
column3: and to determine if new drug coatings will improve drug exposure so that it can be taken orally once per day. Success of this project will provide vital data needed to support clinical translation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011010^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011010"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Elucidating the function of host-derived cysteine in bacterial virulence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Our immune system responds to stomach infection with Helicobacter pylori by producing high levels of defence molecules called reactive oxygen species (ROS). However
column3: H. pylori can withstand ROS
column4: and they fail to clear the infection
column5: but in the long term
column6: ROS damage the stomach lining resulting in disease. This project tests the hypothesis that H. pylori uses amino acids cysteine and cystine available in the stomach lining to combat ROS. The outcomes will aid future design of new antimicrobials."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011020^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011020"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Cytotoxic T cell granules â a matter of life and death
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Humans are protected from infections and cancer by a subset of immune cells called cytotoxic lymphocytes
column3: which can recognised and kill rogue cells. Despite an enormous clinical interest
column4: how these cells mature from a naive inactive to a fully activated state is poorly understood. The aim of the current proposal is to investigate that process
column5: and thus provide a better understanding of how the immune system works and how it can be better utilised to treat cancer and other diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011033^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011033"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"ComBATing lethal prostate cancer with combination Bipolar Androgen Therapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"For 80 years
column3: the main way to treat advanced prostate cancer has been to cut off the supply of male hormones. Unfortunately
column4: this only works temporarily and it compromises quality of life. Surprisingly
column5: new clinical trials show that the opposite approach â supplying excess testosterone â is effective and improves quality of life. Our novel idea is to boost the efficacy of testosterone therapy
column6: and ensure more patients benefit
column7: by combining it with a second drug."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011042^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011042"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Establishing a new bone pathologic pathway and solving problems of diagnosis in chronic orthopaedic infections
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Orthopaedic and other bone infections are difficult to diagnose
column3: treat and cure. Hard bone is a unique niche for host-pathogen interaction that provides both serious treatment challenges and new opportunities for improving patient outcomes. Using analysis of human patients
column4: unique animal and human models of bone infection
column5: our proposal will revolutionise diagnosis and understanding of complex infections such as periprosthetic joint infection and diabetic foot infection."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011044^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011044"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"COMBAT - A Combination B-and T-Cell Epitope Vaccine to Futureproof COVID-19 Vaccine
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We are proposing a vaccine that contains only safe components of the SARS-CoV-2 virus
column3: yet effectively elicits protective immunity. The vaccine works by inducing antibodies capable of preventing the virus from attaching to lung cells
column4: and killer T cells that destroy virus-infected cells. This highly innovative approach will generate a much needed safe and prophylactic 2nd generation modular vaccine
column5: ideal for âvaccine updateâ that will have a major impact on health and society more generally."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011047^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011047"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Immunoglobulin A degradation by the gut microbiome
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The antibody immunoglobulin A (IgA) plays an important role in the immune response to microbial species at mucosal surfaces. Pathogenic bacterial species are known to degrade IgA in the gut to aid their virulence; however
column3: little is known about this activity in commensal bacteria. Here
column4: we aim to study a novel protein identified in a gut commensal bacterium that can potentially degrade IgA
column5: and determine if this protein activity has downstream consequences to disease susceptibility."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011083^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011083"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mapping the Beneficial Effects of Exercise in humans using Personalised Phosphoproteomics
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Exercise has major health benefits and can prevent many diseases. For example
column3: it is very effective in diabetes by improving insulin action. However
column4: exercise is poorly tolerated by many creating a need to define the mechanism for these benefits. Using cutting-edge technologies we have identified a new lead that might underpin exercise effects on insulin action. This project will characterise this novel pathway in humans
column5: bringing us a step closer to finding a drug that mimics exercise."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011115^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011115"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the inflammatory T cell landscape in ankylosing spondylitis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Ankylosing spondylitis
column3: or AS for short
column4: is a common inflammatory arthritis that affects joints of the spine and pelvis. There is no cure for AS. Cells of the immune system called T cells are known to be important in AS but the details of how these cells work in the disease are unclear. Our work will define exactly how T cells work in AS. This world-first knowledge will permit design of new treatments focused specifically on preventing harmful aspects of T cell function that contribute to AS."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011119^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011119"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Legumain at the cutting edge of oral cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Oral cancer patients suffer from profound pain and the survival rate is low due to the spread of the cancer. Effective therapies to treat oral cancer pain and prevent its spread are currently lacking. We have identified an enzyme that promotes cancer pain
column3: and drugs that block its activity are effective at relieving pain. We will test the contribution of this enzyme to cancer spread and determine whether drugs blocking its activity are effective at preventing spread and alleviating pain."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011120^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011120"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"When sporadic disease is not sporadic - exploiting cryptic relatedness to unravel MND genetics
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with a significant genetic component underlying both the hereditary and sporadic forms of disease. Using a global cohort of ~10
column3: 000 ALS cases
column4: we aim to uncover unrecognised ancestral relationships between patients in order to detect new genes that cause ALS or influence the progression of the disease. We will also harness the power of artificial intelligence to predict prognosis and inform clinical care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011129^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011129"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Vaccine nonspecific effects of live and non-live vaccines: understanding the mechanisms and potential consequences.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Increasing evidence suggests that in addition to protecting us against specific diseases
column3: vaccines can also confer nonspecific effects that are defined as effects on health unrelated to the disease targeted by the vaccine. In this proposal
column4: we will investigate how different vaccines may shape how our innate immune system responds to subsequent infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011143^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011143"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Evaluating anti-fibrotic drugs for intracochlear fibrosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cochlear implantation is currently the best method for hearing restoration and has been shown to improve speech understanding in the majority of patients. The acute and long-term outcomes of cochlear implantation remain variable and can be unpredictable. One reason for this variability is the formation of scar tissue around the electrode which
column3: in some cases can lead to device failure. In this study we will determine if anti-fibrotic drugs can reduce the formation of this scar tissue."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011172^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011172"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A new role for gut pH in blood pressure regulation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"High blood pressure continues to be a major
column3: poorly controlled but modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular death. Diets high in fibre are associated with lower blood pressure via the production of substances as a result of fibre digestion by gut microbes. We found that these same substances lower gut pH. This new mechanism could have major implications for the management of hypertension in the future."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011193^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011193"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a nociceptive measuring device capable of differentiating chronic pain states
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Pain measurement is an essential element in any medical assessment
column3: including diagnosis
column4: monitoring of disease progress and evaluation of treatment effectiveness
column5: but there is no common or easy method of objective pain measurement. This study aims to create an biosensor "neuron-on-chip" cell-based device with the machine learning driven capacity to measure and discriminate between various chronic types by analysing serum samples from animal models of chronic pain and human patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011200^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011200"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel therapies for slowing vision loss caused by retinal degeneration
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Death of the light sensitive cells of the eye
column3: the photoreceptors
column4: is one of the leading causes of visual impairment in Australia. Our data indicate accumulation of intracellular waste within photoreceptors is a critical driver of their death. The aims of this project are to define the molecular pathways causing waste accumulation and find treatments that enhance waste recycling in photoreceptors to slow the devastating progression of vision loss."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011209^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011209"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mapping sex differences in the journey of an individual with coronary heart disease through the healthcare system
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A general practice visit is often the first point of contact with the health system and a gateway to other specialist health services. However
column3: data from different services are not easily âjoined upâ making it difficult to look across the patientâs care journey. This project will join all health attendances for patients with heart related symptoms. This high-quality âjoined upâ research will contribute to improvements in the provision of health services and patient outcomes in Australia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011217^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011217"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"TARGETING DEREGULATED EPIGENETIC MECHANISMS IN LYMPHOMA
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Diffuse large B-cell lymphomas (DLBCL) are aggressive tumors
column3: with 40% patients not responding to the conventional chemotherapy treatment or relapsing after treatment. In this proposal
column4: we will evaluate new epigenetic therapies to treat these lymphomas
column5: targeting the non-inherited environmental factors that control the function of genes. We predict that the results from this project will drive new clinical trials for DLBCL patients with TET2 or CREBBP mutations
column6: which represent 1 in 3 patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011220^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011220"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Regenerative surgery for liver disease using human iPSC-derived liver organoids
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will develop a new treatment for liver disease. Using a patientâs own stem cells
column3: we will generate the key components of liver tissue and combine this into mini-liver units called organoids. Organoids will be transplanted into the body (in the groin)
column4: for initial development around a major artery/vein
column5: forming a âsecond liverâ in the body. We will then remove diseased liver tissue and replace this with the second liver
column6: in a surgical procedure similar to liver transplantation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011299^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011299"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Deciphering incomplete penetrance of subfertility
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Infertility is one of the most common chronic health issues involving young adults. Infertility has many causes and is associated with other conditions including elevated risk of type 2 diabetes
column3: heart disease and mental health issues such as anxiety and depression. The goal of the project is to discover genes that influence female fertility levels. This work is crucial to bridge the gap between accurately predicting who is at risk of infertility and how best to treat patients as individuals."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011314^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011314"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Generating a higher order kidney by understanding and controlling nephron connectivity
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Engineering replacement kidney tissue for the treatment of chronic kidney disease has the potential to revolutionise kidney disease treatment. We previously used human stem cells to generate many nephrons
column3: the filtering units of the kidney. In this project
column4: we will focus on how to induce connections between these nephrons to ensure a common path for urine exit. This will bring us one stem closer to a stem-cell derived replacement kidney."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011334^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011334"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Can psychedelics treat anorexia nervosa? Insights into the therapeutic effects of psilocybin in an animal model
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a debilitating disorder which is currently untreatable. Phase 1 clinical trials of psilocybin are underway in patients with AN
column3: however the biological mechanisms of psilocybin remain inadequately understood. This project
column4: which will inform patient selection to avoid unfavourable effects
column5: utilises the activity-based anorexia rat model combined with sophisticated techniques to furnish an understanding of psilocybinâs actions on weight loss
column6: cognition and brain function."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011342^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011342"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel modelling of childhood obesity to improve decision making and close the gap
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Children from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander
column3: other culturally and linguistically diverse groups
column4: and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups are most affected by obesity. We will use novel modelling methods to assess childhood obesity prevention programs for future savings in healthcare costs
column5: improvements in quality of life and impacts on inequalities. We will work with relevant stakeholders to ensure that resources are prioritised for the best and fairest obesity prevention programs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011344^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011344"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Elucidating the impact of oxidative stress on the early development of human placental villi using human stem cell derived placentoids
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The placenta supports the life of the baby. Nutrients
column3: waste and oxygen cross special placental cells (trophoblasts) at the boundary between fetal and maternal circulation. Early in pregnancy
column4: trophoblasts may experience premature rises in oxygen levels that can damage the placenta and risk maternal and fetal health. A newly developed experimental system will be used to study how oxygen fluxes impact trophoblast health to better understand the cause of placental defects at the cellular level."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011355^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011355"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New strategy to safely and effectively reduce diabetic kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) is a catastrophic disease with no effective treatment to reduce scarring and inflammation
column3: the major pathological features of DKD. We have found a new target and generated a prototype drug
column4: CHA-061
column5: to safely inhibit this target
column6: which led to concurrent inhibition of inflammation and fibrosis in animal models of DKD. This grant will study the structure-activity relationship of this prototype inhibitor in order to generate a more effective therapy to combat DKD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011391^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011391"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing novel CAR T cell therapy approaches to treat prostate cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in Australian men and second leading cause of death. The major clinical challenge is to offer more effective treatments for men with advanced prostate cancer
column3: particularly those who have failed all available therapies. This project will provide preclinical evidence that CAR T cell immunotherapy is effective for prostate cancer and will inform future clinical trial development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011398^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011398"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a defective interfering RNA based antiviral approach to treat infections by SARS-CoV-2 and emerging variants
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Specific therapy for severe disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 is limited. The ability of viruses to become resistant to a therapy may be obstacle for antiviral development. This project develops a unique platform
column3: using virus-specific antiviral RNA
column4: as a unique and possibly âantiviral-resistanceâ proof approach that could be deployed as a therapeutic for COVID-19 and also help to solve the challenge of viral pandemics from known and unknown viruses
column5: especially other human pathogenic coronaviruses."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011447^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011447"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel single treatment for two serious complications of allogeneic stem cell transplantation: acute graft-versus-host disease and sinusoidal obstruction syndrome.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Acute graft versus host disease (GVHD) is a frequent and devastating complication of allogeneic stem cell transplantation
column3: which is the use of stem cells from a donor related or unrelated to the patient who is the recipient. It is mediated by immune activation and inflammation. We have developed a new drug (Anti-VCAM-CD39) that has anti-inflammatory and immune suppressive properties. We will test the efficacy of this drug to simultaneously treat GVHD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011462^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011462"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The role of memory engrams in the cortex
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Memory formation is one of the great mysteries of the brain. Memories are not only crucial for survival
column3: but they make us who we are. This project will address where
column4: and how
column5: memories are formed in the brain and provide insight into new targets to treat disorders of memory."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011467^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011467"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the impact of chronic lung disease on COVID-19 and developing effective therapies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"COVID-19 disease is driven by virus-induced
column3: hyper-inflammation that damages the lungs. Patients with chronic lung disease
column4: such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and tuberculosis (TB)
column5: have increased severity of COVID-19 disease. Using our models of TB and smoking-induced COPD
column6: we will define how chronic lung disease increases the severity of COVID-19
column7: how CoV2 infection exacerbates TB and COPD
column8: and identify effective drugs that suppress this inflammatory damage to the lung."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011471^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011471"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Optogenetic restoration of high-sensitivity vision with ChRmine
column2: a novel Type I opsin
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Inherited retinal disease (IRD) is the commonest cause of blindness in people of working age. Sight loss in IRD is due to the loss of light-sensitive cells inside the eye called the rods and cones. However
column4: the light-insensitive nerve cells in the eye
column5: which normally relay information from the rods and cones to the brain
column6: persist. This project aims to introduce a new
column7: highly light-sensitive protein called ChRmine into these cells to make them light-sensitive
column8: thereby restoring vision."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011481^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011481"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Characterisation of novel genetic variants in Hyperekplexia and Dravet Syndrome: Identifying the Unknown Knowns
column2: Ideas Grants"^"All people carry 3 million points-of-variation (variants) in their individual genetic code which can be accurately read but only partially interpreted. This study
column3: with collective world-wide efforts of neurologists and scientists
column4: will enhance our interpretation of variants that are overlooked in routine clinical genetic testing. Outcomes of this study will improve our understanding of neurological disorders and provide a methodological pathway to rapidly detect the splicing variant defects."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011513^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011513"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Intraneuronal Immunotherapy to treat Alzheimerâs Disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Dementia is the single greatest cause of disability in older Australians and the second leading cause of death. At present
column3: dementia can only be managed through symptomatic treatment with limited therapeutic effects. Current immunotherapies for dementia are limited to the small amount of toxic protein accessible outside neurons. This project will develop new immunotherapeutics that clear problematic proteins inside neurons in order to halt and reverse the course of dementia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011540^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011540"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of multifaceted glucose-plus therapies - A focus on Hexosaminidase A (HEXA)
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a cause of heart attacks
column3: stroke
column4: and kidney failure. Patients with T2D also commonly suffer from liver disease and increased blood lipids. We have recently identified Hexosaminidase A (HEXA) as a protein secreted by the liver that reduces high blood glucose levels and blood lipids
column5: and improves insulin sensitivity and liver disease in diabetic mice. This project will investigate if HEXA is a useful therapeutic target for the treatment of metabolic disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011547^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011547"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Human pain genes as a window into pain mechanisms and modern pain management
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Chronic pain affects ~20% of the adult population at any one time
column3: most people will suffer from chronic pain at some stage in their lives
column4: and available pain treatments do not help the majority of pain patients. In this project we use new genomic knowledge and techniques to gain basic insight into pain biology and develop new gene editing therapies to treat extreme untreatable chronic pain."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011557^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011557"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A microRNA NanoChip Technology for Predicting Childhood Type 1 Diabetes Risk
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Type 1 diabetes (T1D) involves destruction of insulin-producing cells. Current clinical tests
column3: although useful to diagnose T1D
column4: cannot accurately predict future T1D as they measure blood-based molecules that arise following the destruction of insulin producing cells. Through this study
column5: we use a novel test (like a pregnancy test) that offers the capacity to measure a different class of blood-based molecules
column6: which can help identifying T1D progression. Early detection can help prevent diabetes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011558^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011558"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigation of novel immune pathways for improving cancer immunotherapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract separates our body from the intestinal content. Its barrier function is crucially promoted by immune cells named intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) that sense cellular stress and recognise microbial agents. We show that IELs play a critical role in preventing bowel cancer progression. We will discover new genes and molecular pathways that promote the anti-cancer functions of IELs
column3: leading to discovery of novel drug targets to treat bowel cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011560^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011560"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Breast Cancer Dormancy - Mechanisms and Development of Rational New Therapies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Over 85% of breast cancer deaths are caused by the spread of the cancer cells to vital organs
column3: leading to organ failure and death. Once these secondary tumours establish
column4: our current therapies are not effective
column5: at best
column6: they delay the growth and further spread of the cancer. Tumour cells can lie dormant for up to 20 years before relapse. The aim of this project is to test novel therapies for their ability to kill these dormant tumour cells before they can grow into new tumours."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011584^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011584"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting necroptosis in the race to treat acute and chronic inflammation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Necroptosis
column3: a form of programmed cell death
column4: is an important weapon used by our bodies to prevent the spread of viruses
column5: bacteria and even cancer. We have discovered that many populations have developed genetic changes that may enhance necroptosis and increase inflammation in the body. We propose that these changes are the key to understanding why only some people develop severe life threatening symptoms to infections
column6: and the key to designing more effective therapies for inflammatory diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011590^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011590"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Glioblastoma - inhibition of P2X7R as a potential therapeutic target for treatment of this aggressive cancer.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Glioblastoma is a highly fatal human brain cancer generally affecting young adults
column3: with survival time of only 12 months after diagnosis despite treatment. Our work is showing very promising results where inhibiting a particular cell membrane protein
column4: P2X7R (with a particular drug AZ10606120) can significantly reduce tumour proliferation. AZ10606120 was better than the currently available chemotherapy
column5: Temozolomide. This is very exciting and warrants urgent further study via this Ideas grant."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011592^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011592"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Normative reference ranges for brain phenotypes in psychiatry
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Psychiatry is one of the few remaining fields in medicine where biological tests are seldom used to inform treatments and guide diagnoses. We aim to improve the utility of brain imaging in psychiatry through the development and provision of healthy reference ranges for measurements of brain structure extracted from a patient's MRI scan. This project charts a way forward towards personalised brain medicine in psychiatry."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011595^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011595"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Prolonging survival in glioblastoma through quiescence inhibition
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Most people diagnosed with the brain cancer glioblastoma die within 15-months. The cancer is so deadly because it rapidly returns after therapy. Glioblastoma returns because of slowly dividing cancer stem cells that resist treatment. Our strategy is to eliminate these cells by forcing them to divide quickly during chemotherapy. This project will test targeted molecules in organoid and pre-clinical animal models of the disease to establish an evidence base for Phase 1 trials."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011627^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011627"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Single Cell Basis for the Emergence of Drug Resistance during Azacitidine Therapy in Myelodysplastic Syndromes and Acute Myeloid Leukemia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Myelodysplasia and acute myeloid leukemia are blood cancers that arise in abnormal blood stem cells in the bone marrow. Azacitidine (AZA) is a drug that helps re-establish blood cell production in ~50% of patients. It is ineffective in the remainder. We will test whether AZA works in responders by improving the fitness of abnormal blood stem cells and their surrounding cells and modulating immune cells that help eliminate abnormal blood cells. This will guide drug discovery for non-responders."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011633^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011633"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel pathways to abstinence from alcohol seeking
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Relapse to drinking after a period of treatment remains a fundamental problem for sufferers of alcohol-use disorders. This project uses a suite of state of the art technologies in a well validated pre-clinical animal model to identify how the brain gates this propensity to relapse. It will provide critical new knowledge on which cells in which brain circuits to target as well as when to target them in order to prevent relapse and promote abstinence from drinking."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011634^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011634"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding Brain Cleaning in Obstructive Sleep Apnoea
column2: Ideas Grants"^"During deep sleep
column3: blood pressure falls and the brain rests. Production of toxic waste also slows while its removal increases. This brain cleaning process during sleep is thought to be crucial for preventing dementia. Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA) is a common condition characterised by marked sleep and blood pressure disturbances. People with OSA have an increased risk for dementia. This study aims to investigate how sleep and blood pressure disturbances affect brain cleaning in people with OSA"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011728^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011728"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting metastatic triple-negative breast cancer with a selective oncogenic JNK inhibitor
