column2: Ideas Grants"^"While JNK is a potent oncogene in TNBC
column3: there are no effective JNK-targeting therapies due to the fact that this signalling pathway regulates numerous cellular functions. Leveraging a recent screen of 114
column4: 000 compounds
column5: we have identified a novel molecule
column6: called K12
column7: that specifically inhibits the tumour promoting activity of JNK. Now
column8: we will further the preclinical evaluation of K12
column9: to generate a world-first drug capable of preventing metastatic outgrowth in TNBC"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011730^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011730"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving the pipeline for translation of therapies for serious complications of pregnancy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction are deadly complications of pregnancy
column3: without current therapies for either. Development of treatments is seriously limited
column4: pregnant women are excluded from drug trials
column5: due to concerns for both mother and baby. We have developed a dedicated pipeline for drug discovery for pregnancy; we will thoroughly test promising drug candidates and advanced delivery strategies. This proposal paves the way for much needed development of therapies for pregnant women."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011733^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011733"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The effects of early exposure to bushfires on adult brain structure and function
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The effects of bushfire smoke inhalation on brain structure and function remain unknown. We will conduct the first systematic study of this issue
column3: based on a cohort of monkeys born during the 2019-2020 bushfire season. The effects of pre- and post-natal bushfire exposure will be investigated in adult brain
column4: using functional and structural MRI
column5: cognitive tests
column6: and neuropathological examination. This project will gain vital scientific data that may help guide future government action."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011747^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011747"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Enabling early ovarian cancer diagnosis and prediction of platinum resistance
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Ovarian cancer often gets diagnosed late
column3: and at that stage survival outcomes are poor. Here
column4: we propose to use a simple drop of blood
column5: to detect combinations of proteins and changes in genetic material originating from cancer and immune cells
column6: to support earlier
column7: more accurate diagnosis and predict platinum resistance to avoid delay of personalised treatment. We also develop easy-to-use
column8: low-cost Lab-on-a Chip devices to enable routine testing and monitoring at the point-of-care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011753^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011753"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Infiltrating central command to selectively alter autonomic function
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The brain controls blood pressure and other internal organ functions that are necessary for life. In disease
column3: this control does not work properly. This can be the cause of diseases like hypertension
column4: but it also seems to happen in neurological conditions. It is not known why. Using a genetically modified virus that we made
column5: we hope to find out exactly which neurons control organ function and then modify their activity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011761^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011761"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel regulator of interferon signalling
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We have identified a new role for a protein called ARAP2 in regulating the immune response to infection. We have generated unique experimental models and have access to immune cells from 25 patients carrying ARAP2 mutations which will enable us to understand the role of ARAP2 in infectious diseases such as TB or Covid-19. This project offers the potential to identify and treat individuals at high risk of life-threatening infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011763^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011763"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing a novel immune check point for cancer killing
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The Project Team aims to test the idea that a patients T cells can be âtunedâ to increase the ability of their own immune system to find
column3: infiltrate
column4: and kill pancreatic cancer cells.This may be beneficial as a stand alone therapy or most likely
column5: work in synergy with emerging immune therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011767^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011767"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Rewriting the dogma of chromatin compaction: a new pathway for polycomb-mediated gene repression in development and disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Polycomb repressive complexes are enzymatic complexes that safeguard the genome by preventing repressed genes from becoming active. The proposed study aimed at identifying how different types of polycomb repressive complexes work together to maintain genes in a compacted state that prevent their expression. The project aims to determine the cascade of molecular events that lead to chromatin compaction and to visualize this process in high resolution."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011768^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011768"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding and Treating Videogame Addiction in Young People
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Excessive videogame play is causing harm to individuals and conflict among families. In the most severe cases players develop Internet Gaming Disorder. We will identify the factors that lead to addiction and based on this we will work with videogame players to design an intervention that will help people overcome IGD. The intervention will be based in software that videogame players are already using. We will evaluate the intervention and translate the knowledge we gain for use by others."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011770^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011770"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Upending the platelet paradigm: Targeting actin-driven membrane budding to modulate platelet production in health and disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Platelets are the cells in the blood responsible for blood clotting and also contribute to wound healing and fighting infection. In a world first
column3: we discovered how the body produces platelets
column4: overturning a 100-year-old dogma. We will capitalise on our breakthrough to understand the diseases of platelet production
column5: develop new therapies to control platelet levels
column6: and generate new knowledge to overcome scalability problems preventing laboratory-based production of platelets for clinical use."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011806^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011806"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Transforming genomic surveillance of foodborne Salmonella infections with SalmonellaTracker: a standardised
column2: high resolution and scalable platform
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Salmonella infections are a major health burden with over 50
column4: 000 cases each year in Australia. Control of this disease requires rapid and accurate strain typing and tracking. In this project we will develop tools for national and international Salmonella genomic surveillance. These tools will facilitate the tracking
column5: control and characterisation of Salmonella in both the human population and in the food production chain
column6: reducing their global health burden."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011845^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011845"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A paradigm shift in lactational mastitis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Lactation mastitis is a debilitating inflammatory breast disease occurring in 1 in 5 Australian breastfeeding women. The disease causes lactation insufficiency
column3: localised pain and rapid onset of fever
column4: muscle aches
column5: chills and fatigue
column6: leading many women to use supplementary formula or cease breastfeeding altogether. This project will address key gaps in our understanding of the biological causes of mastitis and lead to improved prevention and treatment of this disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011853^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011853"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Illumination of Immune Checkpoint Therapy of Cancer: Molecular Imaging of Immunity with Copper Radiopharmaceuticals
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Exciting developments in the treatment of cancer have involved developing ways to reinvigorate a patientâs own immune system to attack their disease. This type of therapy
column3: called immune checkpoint therapy
column4: produces remarkable outcomes for some patients but some do not respond. This research will develop the chemistry required to produce imaging agents to enable clinicians to identify patients suitable for immune checkpoint therapies using non-invasive Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011883^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011883"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Creating Health in a New Home: A transformative approach to building evidence for refugee health across generations
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Refugees experience serious health issues on arrival that demand specialised services. Little is known about refugee health after settlement and over generations and if tailored healthcare is needed. This study will deliver new evidence to plan appropriate cost-effective health services and programs. A roadmap will be designed with refugees to achieve health and evaluate outcomes. This innovative approach will empower refugees
column3: placing them at the centre of their health decision making."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011912^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011912"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Communication training for mental health professionals: developing cultural sensitivity and capability to improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people mental health outcomes
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This interventional study will be led by Indigenous researchers and mental health professionals and engage with Indigenous consumers
column3: communities
column4: services providers and policy makers to co-design
column5: deliver and evaluate a communication training package for non-Indigenous mental health professionals. The goal is to improve health outcomes for Indigenous patients and build an accountable
column6: more knowledgeable and culturally sensitive mental health workforce."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011940^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011940"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"CHIARI MALFORMATION: DEFINING PATHOPHYSIOLOGY AND TREATMENT GOALS
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Chiari I malformation is a complex neurological disorder that has a significant impact on a patientâs quality of life. We do not understand what causes many of the symptoms (debilitating headache &amp; cognitive deficits) and complications (spinal cysts). Indications for surgery and surgical goals are also controversial. This project addresses these knowledge gaps using integrated human studies and machine learning and is expected to develop imaging guidelines for surgical indications and success."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011953^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011953"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a novel glucose lowering medication targeting mTORC1 in osteoblasts.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"New medications to lower blood sugar levels are desperately needed to help treat the many millions of people at risk of developing chronic diseases associated with obesity and Type 2 diabetes (T2DM). Our group has identified a new drug target in bone forming cells. This target becomes over-activated in obesity and decreases the ability of insulin to stimulate sugar uptake. In this proposal
column3: we will develop a novel inhibitor and test the inhibitor in a model system of diet-induced T2DM."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011958^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011958"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New insights for reducing Aboriginal stillbirth: Community-led
column2: integrated evidence for change
column3: Ideas Grants"^"This project will work in partnership with Aboriginal Elders
column4: communities and service providers to undertake the first large-scale examination of stillbirth among Aboriginal peoples. It aims to enhance our understanding of the risks to Aboriginal stillbirth
column5: explore Aboriginal community knowledge and awareness of stillbirth risks
column6: and progress Aboriginal-specific intervention strategies to support stillbirth education and awareness."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011959^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011959"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A FRET-based protein sensor for RNA detection
column2: localisation and analysis
column3: Ideas Grants"^"The ability to detect specific RNA molecules is a key aspect of diagnosis and pathogenesis of a variety of diseases. Recent developments from synthetic biology have provided us with robust designer RNA-binding proteins which can be used as sophisticated tools for detecting specific RNA molecules to understand the molecular basis of numerous diseases. Applying cutting edge âsingle-moleculeâ techniques to prototype molecules we will develop these tools for application as RNA detecting biosensors."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011963^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011963"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving therapeutic delivery of RNA
column2: Ideas Grants"^"RNA based therapies show tremendous promise for treating many important diseases
column3: however an effective method of delivering these drugs to the correct compartment of cells has not yet been discovered. This project will investigate the barriers existing at the cellular level that hinder RNA delivery. This knowledge will be used to engineer nanoparticles to help translate RNA technologies from the laboratory into the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011969^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011969"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Modelling polycystic kidney disease in vitro
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD) causes kidney and liver failure in babies and children. One quarter of babies born with ARPKD will not survive after birth. We have recently developed a method to recreate human kidney tissue from stem cells. We will generate stem cells using patient blood samples and use these to make a model of the patientâs ARPKD disease in the laboratory. We will use these patient models to screen for new
column3: personalised treatments for patients with ARPKD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011978^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011978"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Î±1-adrenoceptor protein structures and selective tools: towards novel treatments for heart failure and Alzheimerâs disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Heart failure and dementia are the top and fifth leading disease burdens in Australia respectively
column3: highlighting the urgent need to identify new ways to treat and relieve the symptoms of these devastating diseases. Adrenaline receptors in our body called a1-adrenoceptors
column4: have been implicated as playing an important role in heart failure and Alzheimerâs disease
column5: but no suitable drugs exist to explore this further. This project will develop such tools using innovative approaches."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011990^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011990"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Pathogenic membranes as therapeutic drug targets
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Resistance of pathogens to drugs continues to emerge and intensify. While host defence peptides (HDPs) are a promising alternative to current drugs
column3: many pathogens have also evolved resistance mechanisms through changes in their cell membrane. This application will apply a range of analytical tools to understand how bacteria change their cell walls in response to HDPs. The results will allow us to design new combination therapies to treat pathogenic infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012006^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012006"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Characterising the unique functional and pathological properties of a novel extracellular RNA binding protein in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"'FUS' is an important protein that causes aggressive
column3: juvenile types of motor neuron disease (MND). FUS is also implicated in the most common sporadic forms of MND (90% of cases)
column4: but the mechanisms involved are unclear. We have found a new form of FUS that is unique because it exists outside the cell
column5: unlike all other MND proteins. Importantly we have found that in MND patients this protein is abnormal. Here we will examine its normal function outside the cell and its role in MND."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012013^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012013"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving the safety and efficacy of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-T cell therapies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Immunotherapy is the âfourth pillarâ of cancer treatment
column3: alongside surgery
column4: radiation and chemotherapy. We are investigating the manipulation of human immune cells to generate new and improved cancer treatments that âtrainâ a patientâs own immune cells to kill tumours. Preliminary results show potential for improved efficacy and patient safety compared to current immunotherapies. This grant will support further development of suitable âtrainedâ cells for potential use in human clinical trials."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012029^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012029"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Identifying brain pathways regulating sympathetic nervous outflow in human hypertension
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Hypertension is characterised by an increase in the activity of the sympathetic nerves. We will use magnetoencephalography
column3: which records the magnetic field generated by brain neurones
column4: coupled with simultaneous direct nerve recording to reveal which neurones in the brain are responsible for the generation of excess nervous activity in individuals with hypertension."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012051^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012051"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a diagnostic platform for preventative wound management
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Early diagnosis
column3: accurate evaluation
column4: and appropriate wound management are vital to prevent the progression of a diabetic foot ulcer to the stage where amputation is required. Currently there are no effective biochemical tools to predict whether a patient will develop a chronic wound. We aim to develop a simple blood-based diagnostic/prognostic device that will provide an early indication of wound risk for people living with diabetes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012072^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012072"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"3D Nuclear Re-organisation Potentiates Genomic Structural Variations in Prostate Cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"When the cell divides not only does the DNA (genome) need to be replicated but so do the chemical modifications on top of the DNA called the âepigenomeâ. Here we ask how the genome and epigenome talk to each other during cell division and how this can go wrong in cancer. We will demonstrate that progressive alterations to our epigenome when the cell divides result in an increased risk of DNA rearrangements and the development of cancer. Our results will open new approaches for cancer strategies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012074^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012074"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The ADEPT study: Adaptive Diagnostics for Emerging Pandemic Threats in regional Australia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will develop regional diagnostic tests for serious infections
column3: using technical advances made against COVID-19. We will apply these rapid
column4: simple to operate technologies in regional Western Australia. This project will involve regional indigenous communities to reduce the physical
column5: mental and cultural harm done when people are shipped out of country to run diagnostic tests for conditions that could be treated with confidence locally when an early
column6: specific diagnosis is available."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012119^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012119"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding the biology of adipose tissue regulatory T cells to treat metabolic disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Our lab has identified a unique population of immune cell found in abdominal fat (Tregs) that functions to regulate glucose metabolism and are anti-inflammatory. In this proposal we aim to characterize the genes and signals found in fat that influence the function of these cells and understand how these signals differ between sexes. We also aim to understand how Tregs communicate with other cells found in fat
column3: which will help us formulate new therapies for obesity and metabolic diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012140^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012140"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Myelin: wrapping up neural circuit function and behaviour
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Almost half of all Australians aged 16-85 will experience mental illness in their life
column3: yet we do not understand the underlying biological processes that contribute to mental ill health. This project aims to show how brain insulation adapts to and regulates brain function and learn how inappropriate insulation could underpin symptoms of mental health disorders."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012142^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012142"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Type 2 diabetes relief by UPR-mediated beta cell protection
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is caused by insulin deficiency
column3: with obesity a strong risk factor. However
column4: only a small fraction of obese individuals develops T2D. Usually the pancreatic Ã-cells increase insulin release. This proposal will test the novel hypothesis that an adaptive response to stress helps Ã-cells increase insulin release and protect against T2D by preventing the conversion of Ã-cells to other pancreatic cell types. The studies are important for the development of novel therapy for T2D."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012166^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012166"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Enhancers as a new target for diagnosing disorders of sex development.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Most human DNA is made up of regions that do not contain genes but instead carry important regulators that increase or decrease gene activity. Those that increase gene activity are called enhancers. This project aims to identify enhancers of genes that control testis or ovary development. We will determine whether disruption of these enhancers leads to a baby being born with a Disorder of Sex Development to improve diagnosis and clinical management of these patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012196^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012196"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel genetic barcoding approach to identify the vulnerabilities of lethal breast cancer clones
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Metastasis is the primary cause of mortality for patients with breast cancer. There is an urgent need to better understand how breast cancer cells spread and resist standard therapy
column3: to ?nd more effective ways to treat patients with metastatic disease. Our project aims at tracking the fate of thousands of human tumour cells during cancer progression to identify the genetic mechanisms responsible for the recurrence of the disease in vital organs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012211^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012211"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"On-Demand
column2: Nanoparticle-Based Analgesia for Musculoskeletal Pain
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Chronic pain associated with musculoskeletal disease causes a major burden on individuals and health care systems. In this study
column4: we will assay changes in whole-animal pain behavior
column5: and pain signaling
column6: in response to therapeutic delivery of designer nanoparticles in models of osteoarthritis and bone cancer pain. This project is exciting because it will provide proof-of-principle for the use of nanoparticles for on-demand
column7: site-specific analgesia for osteoarthritis and bone cancer pain."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012225^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012225"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Uncovering the pathway between gluten immunity and adverse symptoms in coeliac disease and gluten sensitivity to define novel treatments and symptom biomarkers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Coeliac disease and gluten sensitivity are common illnesses in Australia often associated with unpleasant symptoms after gluten is consumed. Symptoms in some patients can be severe and impair quality of life. How gluten causes this is poorly understood. This study aims to understand the pathways that are important in the development of symptoms
column3: the true triggers
column4: and how gluten immunity is involved. This will enable targeted treatments to manage symptoms improving patient health and well-being."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012233^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012233"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Safeguarding health in International Investment Agreements
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The âpost COVID-19 worldâ will require striking a balance between economic recovery and protection of population health. It is essential that International Investment Agreements (IIAs) do not undermine comprehensive and effective health regulation. This project will generate new evidence on 'best practice' health safeguards in IIAs
column3: to prevent challenge to public health policy
column4: and provide resources for the health and investment policy sectors to increase inclusion of strong health safeguards."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012250^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012250"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"USING HUMAN EMBRYONIC TESTIS ORGANOIDS TO MODEL REPRODUCTIVE DISORDERS
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Some babies are born with atypical reproductive organs meaning the sex of the baby is not clear. If the cause is unknown
column3: doctors can be left guessing as to the best treatment. We have recently created a âhuman embryonic testis in a dishâ model from stem cells. Here we will optimise its use to study genetic and environmental causes of reproductive disorders. Our findings will empower families and doctors to choose the right clinical care for these children
column4: improving their health and wellbeing."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012257^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012257"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Phase-Contrast Neuroimaging for Early Detection of Brain Injury at Birth
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Early detection of brain injury that can occur before
column3: during and around the time of birth is critical for the prevention of lifelong intellectual and physical disabilities. However
column4: current imaging techniques are not able to resolve these types of injuries whilst preventative actions can still be taken. We aim to develop novel imaging technologies that will enable subtle brain injuries to be detected early and accurately in order to improve lifelong outcomes for many infants."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012263^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012263"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"TARGETING COLD TUMOURS WITH TRIPLE THERAPY
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Patients with advanced metastatic disease have a very poor clinical outcome and are the main group of patients with an unmet clinical need. We know that very advanced cancers are resistant to the patient's immune system
column3: and immune based therapies. In my program I will address these issues by (1) revealing how the patient's cancer avoids the immune system (2) create new types of T cells which will be resistant to the tumour immune evasion mechanisms (3) translate my findings into the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012271^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012271"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A molecular and biophysical characterisation of host cell contribution to invasion by the Apicomplexan parasites
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Disease causing Apicomplexan parasites
column3: such as those causing malaria or cryptosporidiosis
column4: must overcome the membrane barrier to infect their host cells. We have developed a novel 4D microscopy method to determine how these human pathogens penetrate the host membrane and how the host cell contributes to this process. Identifying which key factors are essential will improve current treatment strategies and give rise to a novel class of host directed therapies against this group of pathogens."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012273^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012273"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Adrenal-Targeted Nanobiotechnology: A Novel Therapy for Adrenal Disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The adrenal gland produces hormones essential for life-long health. Conditions related to the disruption of these hormones affect 4 million Australians annually
column3: at a cost of $2 Billion. Adrenal conditions require life-long drug replacement therapy
column4: with no possibility of a cure. Through the use of a new adrenal specific delivery technology
column5: we aim to develop novel drug treatments and single-injection cures for adrenal disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012285^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012285"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Eliminating hepatitis B in remote Indigenous settings: generating health economic evidence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Chronic infection with hepatitis B (CHB)
column3: which can cause liver disease including liver cancer
column4: is common across NT Indigenous communities. Many people are unaware they have CHB and few engage in care. To address this
column5: the NHMRC funded the HEP B PAST Project (2017) which aims to eliminate CHB from NT Indigenous communities. Results show a highly effective model of care. This new project will generate health economic evidence that is required to embed the HEP B PAST model into standard practice."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012286^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012286"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding the establishment and persistence of community associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) in resource-limited
column2: high-burden settings: How can we reduce the burden of disease?
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) strain ST93 is a potentially dangerous pathogen of particular concern in resource-limited settings. Our research team has recently identified the highlands of Papua New Guinea as a hotspot for MRSA ST93 bone infections. Through this study we will determine the factors that enable the spread and persistence of ST93 in these settings and identify interventions to reduce the impact of ST93 in resource-limited communities."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012287^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012287"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using Cerebrospinal Fluid Liquid Biopsy for Detection of Mosaic Brain Mutations
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Seizures can occur in patients with or without abnormalities in their brain. We have collected spinal fluid from a subset of these patients and we will use this precious resource to determine the contribution of genetic defects to the development of their seizures. The overall contribution of different types of genetic defects to seizures is not completely understood and this knowledge will improve outcomes for patients by ending their diagnostic odyssey and promoting new therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012290^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012290"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The mesenchymal stromal cell paradox â living cell therapy or dying therapeutic cell?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) can dampen inflammation and aid tissue repair
column3: but efforts to improve their clinical utility are hampered by our poor understanding of how they work. We have found that the therapeutic effects of MSCs depend on their cell death
column4: which triggers immune suppression. Instead of focussing on viable MSCs
column5: we will investigate how dying MSCs modify immune responses. Our discoveries will enable more effective cell therapies for a wide range of diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012301^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012301"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting the brain and sympathetic nervous system to improve outcomes in cancer cachexia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cancer cachexia is the wasting of fat and muscle that occurs in late stages of a number of cancers. It is particularly prevalent in pancreatic cancer. One of the known causes for this wasting is increased activity of the sympathetic nervous system (SNS)
column3: also responsible for the 'fight or flight' response to danger. The SNS is under control of the brain
column4: and this project will look at specific brain cells as therapeutic targets for treating cachexia in a mouse model of pancreatic cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012313^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012313"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigating the role of cellular metabolism in regulating antigen presentation and tumour immune escape
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In order to develop and progress
column3: tumours must avoid elimination by the immune system. Understanding the mechanisms that allow tumours to evade the immune system is critical for developing strategies to overcome immune escape and enhance the efficacy of currently existing immunotherapies. This research will investigate the fundamental mechanisms by which aberrant cell metabolism contributes to immune evasion in cancer and identify strategies to restore tumour elimination by the immune system."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012330^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012330"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Enabling next generation radiotherapy for cancer: Development of novel Quality Assurance instrumentation for Proton Therapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Proton Therapy is a new form of radiotherapy that has many benefits over conventional radiotherapy and is particularly useful for childhood cancers. To maximise the benefits of proton therapy
column3: we need to develop instruments called microdosimeters to accurately measure the physical and biological dose of radiation received by the patient. Our research will develop and test a novel microdosimeter for proton therapy to coincide with the opening of the new Australian Bragg Centre for Proton Therapy"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012342^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012342"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Does Chlamydia infection damage the ovary and compromise fertility?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The ability of Chlamydia to infect and damage the ovary has never been investigated. We will determine exactly how Chlamydia infects and damages ovarian tissues by studying aspects of ovarian function including hormone production
column3: egg health
column4: and fertility in our unique mouse model
column5: and a cohort of human samples. We will also assess whether antibiotics
column6: and our newly developed Chlamydia vaccine
column7: can protect against ovary damage."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012351^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012351"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploring the therapeutic potential of genetically engineering macrophages with a Chimeric Signaling Switch Receptor in kidney diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Kidney diseases are a major cause of death and morbidity worldwide. Current treatments to delay progression of kidney diseases are few and largely ineffective
column3: so that new therapies are urgently needed. We have recently developed an innovative approach to genetically engineer immune cells (macrophages) to treat kidney diseases. This study will determine the effectiveness of this new cell therapy in kidney disease models and whether it can be used to treat human kidney diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012362^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012362"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"IS THE EVOLUTIONARY LOSS OF ACTN3 DETRIMENTAL IN MODERN SOCIETY?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Do you feel the cold or are you happiest in the depths of winter? A common null polymorphism in the skeletal muscle gene ACTN3 (R577X) has been described as a key gene during modern evolution due to its ability to improve muscle function and metabolism following cold exposure. We will explore the impacts of this gene further in modern humans by studying muscles from healthy and obese ACTN3 R577X mice and humans to determine how our ACTN3 genotype influences life in todays modern society."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012370^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012370"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development and mechanistic analysis of novel inhibitors of the dengue virus NS1 protein
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mosquito-borne flaviviruses such as dengue virus (DENV) cause significant morbidity and mortality in tropical and sub-tropical areas worldwide. The DENV NS1 protein is critical to multiple aspects of the viral life cycle and DENV pathogenesis
column3: making it an appealing target of future antiviral therapies. In this project we will apply a rational multi-disciplinary approach to identify and mechanistically characterise unique NS1-targeting antiviral drugs and future NS1-related drug targets."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012371^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012371"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting dysregulated transcription in cancer through Cyclin-Dependent-Kinase 11
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Many proteins cooperate to carefully control which genes are âonâ or âoffâ in our cells. Defects in gene control that cause cells to grow faster and to live longer than normal give rise to cancer. I will investigate the activity of a group of proteins called Cyclin-dependent-kinases (CDKs)
column3: that are essential for ensuring proper gene control and are essential for cancer cells to survive. This will allow us to design better strategies to block the activity of CDKs to kill cancer cells."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012373^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012373"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Determining the role of Target of Rapamycin Complex 2 (TORC2) in cancer cell proliferation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In normal cells
column3: proliferation depends on the availability of nutrients. Tumour cells are usually ânutritionally stressedâ but survive despite this. This project aims to study the cellâs nutrient sensor â TOR Complex 2 â in order to elucidate how it facilitates cell division under nutrient stress. Better understanding of TORC2 signalling will improve future treatment strategies for patients with solid tumours."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012382^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012382"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Achieving benefit without harm: a next-generation glucocorticoid replacement
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Over 2% of the worldâs population takes long-term steroid therapy to control unwanted immune system activity
column3: despite the predictable
column4: harmful side effects of steroids. A natural anti-inflammatory protein
column5: GILZ
column6: is increased as a result of steroid treatment
column7: which is an important way that steroids work. Our studies will lead to a strategy to develop a drug that increases GILZ without the use of steroids
column8: bringing about the protective effects of steroids without the harmful side effects."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012393^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012393"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The contribution of the gut to bipolar disorder
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bipolar disorder is a severe mental illness affecting many Australians. We provide evidence that specific gut cells may trigger the mood fluctuations that are central in bipolar disorders. Activation of these cells can alter brain activity via a pathway called the gut brain axis. This project will focus on understanding how serotonin release from these cells affects brain function in bipolar disorder and how we can target these cells to create new treatments for this disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012404^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012404"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Removing mosquito populations by releasing incompatible males: a species specific biocontrol for urban arbovirus vectors
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Two mosquitoes
column3: Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus
column4: drive the global expansion of arboviruses such as dengue and Zika; both threaten Australia. With no effective vaccines and extensive insecticide resistance
column5: new mosquito control tools are vital. By releasing reproductively incompatible males (males donât bite)
column6: we have successfully reduced aegypti populations in some Queensland towns by over 80% . We will now develop this technology into an efficient deployable product for Australia and beyond."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012418^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012418"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Applying reverse translation to the parkrun phenomenon to identify effective
column2: sustainable methods for scaling-up public health interventions
column3: Ideas Grants"^"parkrun is a free
column4: weekly organised grass-roots mass physical activity event
column5: which has spread across 23 countries with over six million registrants. It has succeeded where most researcher and government-led physical activity interventions have failed in terms of high participation
column6: accessibility and sustainability. Our proposal analyses how parkrun has disseminated and been sustained throughout Australia and will derive models and principles to inform future public health interventions."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012427^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012427"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Studying the persisting glial dysfunction occurring after preterm brain injury to uncover new therapeutic targets
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We cannot treat brain damage in prematurely born babies despite it often leading to permanent brain injury and disability. Cells called glia are vital for building the brain and keeping it healthy. After early-life brain injury
column3: we are learning that glia cannot perform these tasks as they should for many months. In this project
column4: we will test if helping glia 'get back to workâ in the weeks or months after injury might be a way to repair the damaging effects of preterm birth."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012443^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012443"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving respiratory support for preterm infants at birth
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In Australia
column3: 92% of babies born very preterm need help to breathe at birth
column4: which can injure their lungs and brains. While providing respiratory support with a face mask is the gentlest approach
column5: it often fails because the babyâs vocal cords reflexly close if they stop breathing
column6: which prevents air from entering their lungs. Our research focuses on helping these babies breathe at birth to improve the success of providing gentle respiratory support."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012453^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012453"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Communication via epigenetic mechanisms: cell cross-talk and male fertility
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Male infertility is on the rise in Western society but the processes that drive sperm production are still poorly understood. We discovered a new epigenetics-based process that involves the transfer of important information between different cell types in the testis that is critical for the production of viable sperm. We aim to uncover the molecular mechanism of this process
column3: which will provide new insights into the causes of male infertility."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012454^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012454"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Engineering chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells that induce host anti-tumour immunity
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will further enhance the therapeutic application of a gene-engineering based immune therapy involving a patients' own cells. To date this form of therapy has been effective in blood cancers but not solid tumours. We will aim to overcome this by developing technological and scientific advances which will make the immune cells more effective against solid tumours. These findings have the potential to provide treatment options for late stage solid tumour cancer patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012463^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012463"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigation of the structure of the influenza A virus genome and how it directs reassortment to generate novel strains
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Pandemic influenza viruses acquire new properties through the swapping of gene segments known as reassortment. We will investigate the structure of the influenza A virus genome to dissect the molecular mechanism that enables specific genes to interact and be co-selected during reassortment. Our work will provide key insights into the probability of viruses with particular gene constellations emerging in the future
column3: that will greatly benefit pandemic assessment and planning."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012471^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012471"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Eliminating HIV-infected macrophages; a neglected problem in HIV cure research
column2: Ideas Grants"^"HIV cannot currently be cured due to the persistence of âsilentâ sources of HIV hidden within certain cells which are not sensitive to anti-HIV drugs. One type of immune cell that HIV hides in are called macrophages
column3: and these cells are very hard for the immune system to destroy. We will study HIV infection in macrophages and identify ways to âwake upâ silent HIV in these cells and weaken them so that they can be eliminated from the body."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012474^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012474"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Opening the pathway to large data-driven patient-specific diagnostics using novel coronary angiogram analysis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This work will reform the medical practice of risk assessment for coronary artery disease and acute coronary artery syndrome by delivering the next generation of rapid
column3: patient-specific
column4: and high accuracy medical image-based risk assessment. Using innovative state-of-the-art engineering methods
column5: including machine learning
column6: large-scale computational modelling and image analysis
column7: we will reveal new markers of cardiovascular risk in individuals for improved standard clinical care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012475^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012475"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"CRISPR Engineering of CAR T Cells to Enhance Efficacy in Solid Tumours
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will further enhance the therapeutic application of a gene-engineering based immune therapy involving a patients' own cells. To date this form of therapy has been effective in blood cancers but not solid tumours. We will aim to overcome this by developing technological and scientific advances which will make the immune cells more effective against solid tumours. These findings have the potential to provide treatment options for late stage solid tumour cancer patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012498^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012498"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Pursuing IRF4 as a therapeutic opportunity for lymphoid malignancies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The molecule IRF4 is essential to the function of the immune system. In this application we investigate mouse models with mutations in IRF4 that are identical to those found in patients with cancers of the immune system. We will investigate how these mutations affect binding of IRF4 to the DNA and how changes in the IRF4-DNA binding domain lead to formation of tumours and how this interaction can be targeted therapeutically."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012500^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012500"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mosquito-specific viruses: novel agents to control the transmission of arboviral pathogens
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Insect-specific viruses are benign viruses that infect only insects and are transmitted from the insect to their offspring. We and others have shown that infection of mosquitoes with these benign viruses can inhibit infection of these mosquitoes by other viruses that cause human disease. In this grant
column3: we plan to produce one or more strains of mosquitoes harboring these benign viruses for use in biological control programs against mosquito-borne diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012505^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012505"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using population-based data to improve maternal asthma management and offspring health and development
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Asthma affects more than 30
column3: 000 Australian pregnancies each year and has been associated with a range of adverse pregnancy outcomes. This project will utilise population-based data to examine the effects of maternal asthma
column4: as well as the use of individual asthma treatments during pregnancy
column5: on child health and development from birth to 14-years of age and will provide direct evidence to support improvements in policy and practice related to optimising asthma management during pregnancy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012513^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012513"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving the Diagnosis of Barrettâs Oesophagus with Dysplasia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Some patients with Barrettâs oesophagus are at greatly increased risk of developing oesophageal adenocarcinoma
column3: the most common form of oesophageal cancer in Australia. Unfortunately
column4: the current examination method is unreliable for diagnosing these patients prior to cancer
column5: or for accurately predicting cancer risk. We will investigate a molecular test and the potential to develop an antibody test to improve diagnosis and prediction of cancer risk
column6: and possibly reduce healthcare costs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012523^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012523"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A new way to see endometriosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Endometriosis
column3: a chronic and painful condition
column4: affects ~10% women of reproductive age
column5: and is characterized by growth of uterine-like cells outside the uterus such as the pelvis. However
column6: why cells of the uterus end up in other parts of the body
column7: and how they cause pain and other symptoms
column8: are not well understood. This project will address these questions by studying the fundamental biology and function of uterine cells and exploring new diagnostic and therapeutic options for endometriosis."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012530^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012530"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing a novel insulin receptor binding mechanism to therapeutic benefit
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We aim to develop new insulin molecules that provide better blood glucose control to Type 1 and late stage Type 2 diabetic patients. A fascinating discovery from investigations of marine cone snail venom has provided the basis to develop a new class of diabetes therapeutics built on a cone snail derived "mini" insulin scaffold. This proposal outlines the steps required to translate our findings into the development of ultra fast acting insulin analogues for diabetes treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012535^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012535"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"iHSCs
column2: repopulating haematopoietic stem cells derived from human pluripotent stem cells
column3: Ideas Grants"^"The ability to make blood stem cells from human pluripotent stem cells would be beneficial for patients with leukaemia or bone marrow failure who cannot find a matched donor. We will compare the blood stem cells that we can now make in the laboratory with stem cells present in umbilical cord blood and we will use these comparisons to inform improvements in our methods. Success in this project will accelerate the translation of these human stem cell derived blood therapies to the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012552^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012552"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Sex-differences in cellular aging and cardiovascular disease: Role of the AngIV/IRAP axis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"High blood pressure and ageing increase the risk of heart disease. Young women are protected from heart disease
column3: but lose this protection with age. Senolytics are a new class of drug that remove damaged (senescent) cells from the body. Senescent cells lose the ability to self-repair and trigger a cascade of reactions to promote disease. We will determine if a novel enzyme insulin-regulated aminopeptidase (IRAP) causes cell damage and disease
column4: and test the efficacy of IRAP inhibitors."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012560^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012560"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Multi-analyte liquid biopsy-based biomarkers for oropharyngeal cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Throat cancer affects individuals at a relatively young age
column3: who often go on to suffer from long-term treatment related morbidities. In addition
column4: 20% of throat cancers reoccur. There is a desire to reduce the intensity of treatment to lessen severe side effects as well as to monitor response to treatment . We propose to use non-invasive
column5: novel biomarkers to address these unmet clinical needs
column6: thereby improving quality of life for cancer patients and significantly cutting healthcare costs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012567^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012567"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Pioneering novel therapeutic strategies to enhance an anti-tumour immune response in Neuroblastoma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Neuroblastoma has one of the lowest survival rates of all childhood cancers. Immunotherapy stimulates an immune response against cancer cells yet still works poorly in neuroblastoma. This suggests that understanding how neuroblastoma evade immune system is critical to improving such therapies. Our research has found that copper plays a key role in tumours to evade the immune response. We are currently developing new strategies to reduce copper and activate the anti-tumour immune responses."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012569^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012569"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Only a matter of time? A comparison of caloric restriction versus time restriction of food intake.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The proposed study will compare the health benefits of limiting âwhenâ vs âhow muchâ is eaten on health in individuals at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes. The concept that marked improvements in health can be achieved by aligning food intake with circadian rhythms
column3: without weight loss
column4: is game changing. But we do not yet clearly understand how one performs against the other
column5: or if both are required
column6: in humans
column7: since no trials have been performed."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012579^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012579"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining Chemotactic Signalling Networks to Identify New Anti-inflammatory Targets
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A key feature of inflammatory diseases is infiltration of the affected tissues by white blood cells. White blood cell migration is controlled by âchemokineâ proteins that are produced in the tissues and activate receptor proteins on the blood cells. This project will characterise the molecular events leading from receptor activation to white blood cell migration. The results will guide development of medicines to control inflammatory diseases
column3: including atherosclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012582^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012582"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel approach integrating genomics into the health economic modelling of therapeutics
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Despite the increasing uptake of health economic models in practice
column3: greater understanding of the impact of lifetime disease risk in costs and outcomes is fundamental for cardiovascular disease. This research project will utilise an innovative approach in health economic modelling that will provide evidence for the first time on the cost-effectiveness of new interventions. This in return will inform government policies
column4: lead to efficient access to preventive therapeutics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012583^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012583"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeted Delivery of Nucleic Acid Therapeutics for Preventing Preterm Birth
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Thousands of babies could be saved each year with a timely intervention for preterm birth. Current approaches are hampered by a lack of drug specificity. To address this
column3: we first developed uterine-targeted nanocarriers for targeting interventions to the pregnant uterus. We now seek to leverage this platform for the targeted delivery of nucleic acid therapeutics. This bold strategy aims to modulate cellular phenotype in order to block the premature uterine contractions that cause preterm birth."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012600^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012600"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New pathways to improved stroke outcome: the importance of managing intracranial pressure.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Stroke is caused by a loss of blood supply that results in brain tissue death leading to disability. Delayed expansion of stroke injury can occur in the 24-48 hours after stroke. What causes this was previously unknown. We found that an increase in cerebrospinal fluid pressure that affects blood flow to the injury site is likely to blame. We have evidence that a change in the composition of cerebrospinal fluid drives this increase in pressure and we aim to design therapies to prevent it."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012601^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012601"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Leveraging innovative multi-omic approaches to understand and predict myeloma disease development
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Multiple myeloma is a fatal bone marrow cancer which is universally preceded by a pre-cancerous stage known as MGUS. We currently have no way of identifying which MGUS patients will develop myeloma and no treatments to prevent this process. This study will develop clinical tools to identify which MGUS patients are at high risk of developing myeloma
column3: and will identify new therapeutic targets
column4: to revolutionise how we treat MGUS and myeloma and improve outcomes for these patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012620^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012620"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining a protective role for NLRC5 signalling in Helicobacter pylori disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Helicobacter pylori infects the stomach of half the worldâs population and is a major cause of human disease. The body fights H. pylori infection by mobilising white blood cells to the stomach lining
column3: but these responses can lead to lymphoma. We have identified a host protein
column4: NLRC5
column5: as being important in the generation of immune responses that protect against the development of this disease. The project will determine how NLRC5 protects against stomach lymphoma due to H. pylori infection."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012622^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012622"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Location! Location! Location! Geospatial control of memory B cell reactivation in vaccine-induced immunity
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Vaccines are one of the great public health achievements in the modern era. However
column3: vaccinology remains an empirical art and there is an urgent need to advance the science to realize its full potential
column4: particularly in the face of pandemics such as COVID-19 and the emergence of virus variants that require booster injections. Here we propose to track the cell fate trajectories of memory B cells to determine the factors that are critical to generating a potent immune response to vaccination."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012657^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012657"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A new frontier in receptor biology relevant to treatment of disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Disorders of colorectal function
column3: especially constipation
column4: are poorly responsive to drug therapy and are a substantial medical problem. This project should provide insights into the molecular basis for the voluntary defecation response that could provide the basis for novel therapeutic approaches to treat disorders of colorectal function."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012661^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012661"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Making peptide drugs orally bioavailable
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bioactive peptides have exciting therapeutic potential however they are limited by the fact that that they generally can't be taken orally and they don't last very long in the body. The goal of this project is to develop an approach that solves both of these problems and to develop new drug leads for the treatment of chronic pain."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012674^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012674"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Submucosal glands as the origin of Barrettâs oesophagus and oesophageal adenocarcinoma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Barrettâs oesophagus is a relatively common benign condition that arises as a consequence of acid reflux. In some patients
column3: Barrettâs progresses to oesophageal cancer
column4: for which treatments are largely ineffective and thus outcomes are poor. This project addresses a vital gap in our knowledge regarding the cell of origin of Barrettâs oesophagus
column5: which will enable the future development of effective strategies for early intervention or prevention of oesophageal cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012689^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012689"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Do patients with symptoms need a colonoscopy? A novel panel of non-invasive biomarkers to determine need for diagnostic investigation.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Gastrointestinal symptoms can raise concern for bowel cancer
column3: but as they are often non-specific
column4: it is difficult to determine what type of further clinical investigations are needed. There is a need for simple tests to determine the need for colonoscopy. Our study will establish the use of blood and stool tests for identifying disease risk. This will ensure that all symptomatic patients are reviewed for bowel cancer risk with tests that are independent of their symptoms."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012701^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012701"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The role of resident and circulating CD8 T cell memory in the control of liver infections
column2: Ideas Grants"^"CD8+ tissue-resident memory T (Trm) cells are a specialized population of immune cells that act as front-line defenders against pathogens in organs such as the liver. In this study we will investigate how these and other T cells recognise and destroy pathogens like malaria that infect liver cells
column3: without damaging the remaining liver tissue
column4: with the aim of designing better vaccines against liver infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012704^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012704"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Applying machine learning to develop a smart and engaging chatbot to increase physical activity and improve health
column2: Ideas Grants"^"As high levels of physical inactivity lead to a high disease burden in Australia
column3: cost-effective population-based strategies are needed to increase activity levels. The main aim of this project is to develop a very sophisticated chatbot that applies artificial intelligence and machine learning to provide highly personalised physical activity advice
column4: delivered just-in-time
column5: based on real-time data (e.g.
column6: Fitbit
column7: GPS
column8: weather). Our project will enable 'precision medicine' for behavioural health."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012718^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012718"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Effectiveness of empirically based tackle technique intervention to reduce the in-game risk of concussion
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Concussion in collision sports
column3: is a prominent community health concern
column4: occurring mostly during tackles. To make the sport safer for all players
column5: our research will reveal how a rugby playersâ tackles alters their head forces and how retraining their tackle technique can reduce their concussion risk. Our tackle coaching program will have an Indigenous focus as many players identify as Indigenous/Pasifika. We will use this information to develop new coaching guidelines to make the sport safer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012764^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012764"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Chromatin defects in histone mutated brain cancers: from basic mechanisms to novel therapeutic strategies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Paediatric glioblastoma (pGBM) is the most aggressive kind of brain cancer affecting children. To develop treatments for this disease
column3: the underlying molecular mechanisms leading to disease formation must first be understood. This study will investigate how mutations in two key regulators of the genome change DNA integrity and gene activity
column4: leading to the development of pGBM. It will thereby identify new targets for therapeutic intervention strategies."^""^""^""^
