column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012769^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012769"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing the beneficial off-target effects of BCG vaccination to boost protection against SARS-CoV-2
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bacillus CalmetteâGuÃ©rin(BCG)
column3: the vaccine that protects against tuberculosis
column4: also protects against other diseases. This is thought to be because BCG can boost immunity. We will investigate how BCG boosts immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 and if this improves protection against COVID-19 and the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines. We will combine use of mouse models with use of samples from BRACE
column5: our 6800 participant trial testing if BCG vaccination protects against COVID-19 in healthcare workers."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012772^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012772"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Inflammatory Cell Death
column2: Circadian Rhythm & Obesity: A Surprising Triad
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Obesity rates continue to soar despite decades of efforts to promote lifestyle changes. Our work points to an important role for the RIPK1 gene in obesity through adipose tissue inflammation and circadian clock disruption. Using unique mouse models
column4: nanoparticle therapies and novel technologies to map genetic reprogramming
column5: we will explore how RIPK1 pathways drive these processes in obesity and provide proof-of-concept for novel anti-obesity therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012793^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012793"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Macrophage-driven lipid metabolism in health and disease â mechanisms and therapeutic opportunities
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Macrophages are cells of the immune system that are abundant in every organ. We discovered that treating animals with a macrophage growth factor
column3: Colony Stimulating Factor 1 (CSF1)
column4: reduces body fat mass and increases lean mass. This indicates that macrophages responding to CSF1 influence the cross-talk between metabolic tissues that controls energy metabolism and body composition. In this project we will investigate how this occurs and test CSF1 as a therapy for obesity-related complications."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012805^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012805"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel roles for NMDA receptors in cortical processing
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Major psychiatric disorders
column3: like schizophrenia and depression
column4: are thought to arise from subtle changes in brain circuits. A key player in these changes is a protein called the NMDA receptor
column5: which is important for electrical signalling in the brain. This project will study how NMDA receptors normally work in mouse brains to enable the animal to make sense of its environment. The findings will help guide the development of new NMDA receptor-targeting drugs with fewer side-effects."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012809^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012809"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"How the synergy between flavivirus protein and noncoding RNA defeats antiviral response
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Flaviviruses represent a persistent threat with a devastating impact on human health. They have sophisticated mechanisms to subvert and control human antiviral response. One of them is by producing a noncoding RNA. In this project we will obtain an understanding of how these RNAs determine the ability of flaviviruses to evade immune response and establish infection in humans. The outcome will advance our understanding of flavivirus pathogenesis and inform future design of novel antivirals."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012828^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012828"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Circadian clock
column2: sleep
column3: and depression in adolescence: Modelling a novel pathway
column4: Ideas Grants"^"Body clock and sleep undergo significant changes during adolescence
column5: a critical phase for the development of depression. In a large sample of adolescents
column6: we propose to test how later timing of the body clock
column7: shorter sleep duration
column8: and irregular sleep timing
column9: are associated with increased depressive symptoms. We will also test how light exposure patterns affect the shift in timing of the body clock. The study will inform the development of evidence-based sleep interventions for adolescents."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012837^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012837"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Single-cell intravital imaging guides anti-fibrotic therapy to improve standard-of-care treatment in triple negative breast cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Tissue fibrosis is a well-known risk factor for breast cancer initiation
column3: progression and prognosis. It is commonly found in aggressive cancers
column4: such as triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). Fibrosis is also known to protect cancer cells from treatment including chemotherapy
column5: which is the standard-of-care in TNBC. In this proposal we will test the hypothesis that reducing tissue fibrosis can improve standard-of-care performance and outcomes in pre-clinical models of TNBC."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012848^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012848"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Revolutionising immunotherapy response prediction in non-small cell lung cancer via longitudinal single-cell proteomic analysis of liquid biopsy derived cancer and immune cells
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Lung cancer is leading personalised medicine (replacing âone medicine for allâ with drugs targeting unique cancer characteristics)
column3: but that only applies to a small subset of lung cancers with certain characteristics (biomarkers). This proposal uses innovative methods to apply and thourougly test novel biomarkers for lung cancer patients
column4: predicting response to immunotherapy
column5: improving treatment and preventing deadly side-effects. This will transform treatment of Australiaâs most deadly cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012860^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012860"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Restoring anti-tumour immunity in melanoma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Melanoma is a major Australian health problem and a common cause of cancer death in young adults. Two recent types of therapies have revolutionised the treatment of patients with melanoma
column3: and although patient survival has improved
column4: most patients will eventually become resistant to treatment. This research explores how cancer cells evade treatment and reveals cancer vulnerabilities that can be exploited to re-sensitize melanoma to current and new therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012863^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012863"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dissecting the healthy and immunosuppressed
column2: primary and secondary immune responses within human lymph nodes following COVID-19 vaccination
column3: Ideas Grants"^"The dynamics of the immune response to vaccines in human lymph nodes are important in determining eventual vaccine responses but are poorly characterised. We will investigate the critical components of the immune response in human lymph nodes that lead to an effective neutralising antibody response to novel COVID-19 vaccines. Our findings will provide insights into the critical responses required for a successful vaccine and will inform the rational design of future vaccines."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012882^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012882"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"MY Voice Library
column2: Ideas Grants"^"For children with cerebral palsy and speech impairment access to a communication device is imperative. Today
column3: accessing their communication device is often challenging
column4: resulting in 15-20 times slower communication rates compared to those who can speak. This application seeks funding to support the development of a world-first data-driven MY Voice Library
column5: a foundation for research and development of innovative engineering of real-time communication solutions for children with cerebral palsy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012883^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012883"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Predicting and preparing for the unfolding evolution of SARS-CoV-2
column2: Ideas Grants"^"One year on from the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic
column3: variants of SARS-CoV-2 have evolved to be more transmissible
column4: pathogenic and less susceptible to immune responses from infection or vaccination. We propose utilising the deep mutational scanning method to examine the molecular pathogenesis and vaccine escape of SARS-CoV-2 at a single amino acid residue resolution and towards developing a universal vaccine candidate to neutralise all potential future SARS-CoV-2 variants."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012895^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012895"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploiting the neuroprotective effects of the gut microbiome for the treatment of spinocerebellar ataxia-3 and related neurodegenerative diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Spinocerebellar ataxia-3 (SCA3
column3: also known as Machado Joseph disease) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease that causes coordination and mobility problems
column4: leading to paralysis. There is currently no treatment for SCA3. This project will investigate whether the gut microbiome
column5: bacteria that inhabit the gut
column6: and levels of chemicals produced by these microbes are altered in SCA3 patients. We will also investigate a therapeutic strategy to correct the gut microbiome and its products to treat SCA3."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012915^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012915"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Artificial Intelligence to Understand and Predict Chronic Subdural Haematoma Evolution
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project tackles chronic subdural haematoma
column3: a disease caused by bleeding on the brainâs surface that is increasing in incidence due to our ageing population. Artificial intelligence and advanced brain imaging will be used to predict and identify earlier those patients who are likely to need and benefit from treatment. This will personalize patient care
column4: allowing proactive treatment to prevent progression and decrease the burden of disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012929^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012929"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Why do women overeat? Understanding the neural circuits driving stress-related eating
column2: Ideas Grants"^"For women negative emotions such as stress and loneliness are more likely to drive overeating compared to men. There is a dearth of literature detailing the brain circuits driving stress-induced binge eating
column3: particularly in female subjects
column4: as to date no suitable animal model exists. We have developed a highly translational model of stress-induced binge eating in female subjects
column5: which enables us to determine for the first time the neurobiology underlying this specific form of eating behaviour."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012936^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012936"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Making a Niche: an in vitro human bone marrow organoid factory for blood
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The bone marrow is the âfactoryâ where blood cells are made. The ability to recreate a human bone marrow organ from pluripotent stem cells in the laboratory would improve our ability to make blood stem cells for patients with leukaemia or bone marrow failure who cannot find a matched donor. We can now make all the individual componentsâ blood cells
column3: bone
column4: cartilage
column5: blood vessels and stromal cells. In this project we will assemble these into a functioning human bone marrow organ."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012941^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012941"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"High-fidelity tumouroids: accelerating next generation personalised medicine
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Anti-cancer drug testing using in vitro models are unable to recapitulate the complexity of human tumours
column3: hindering the application of more effective therapeutic strategies. We have created ALTEN
column4: a tissue-engineering system capable of preserving tumour biopsies maintaining their original environment. ALTEN allows parallel testing of different therapies on each patientâs biopsy
column5: accurately identifying the most effective treatment for each patient
column6: facilitating a personalised medicine approach."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012943^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012943"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Boosting cellular immunogenicity to combat metastatic cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Spread (metastasis) to bone in breast and prostate cancer is painful and very difficult to treat. We have discovered that cancers growing in bone have developed changes to allow them to go undetected and escape immune control. In this proposal
column3: we will discover ways to reverse these changes and increase response to radiotherapy and immune therapies to target deadly metastatic cancers. This work will offer a new avenue of therapy for bone metastasis that is built on strong biological discoveries."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012971^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2012971"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A20 variants contribute to endemic kidney disease in Tiwi Islanders
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Kidney disease is endemic amongst the Tiwi Islanders with the highest reported rates worldwide. It is thought that 60% of this risk comes from genetics. We have identified six gene variants in a gene likely to be important in controlling progression of kidney disease. These variants impair the ability of the gene to prevent kidney disease and offers a novel treatment target for the Tiwi Islanders."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013024^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013024"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Toward tailored excitation therapy for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Motor neuron disease and associated dementia are significantly debilitating Australians and we have no effective cures. Our work has discovered that the way brain cells communicate in these diseases is disrupted. We propose to develop a new way of treating these diseases
column3: tailored to the part of the brain that is affected. With this knowledge we will investigate new targeted therapies that could prevent brain cells from tipping over from proper brain function to too much excitation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013027^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013027"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Revealing how junctional neural tube defects arise
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The brain and spinal cord control are formed early in development from a common precursor called the neural tube. Each end of the neural tube forms by a different process and how these are united to form a single tube is unknown. Failures in this critical process cause severe birth defects in humans. We will use live imaging of transgenic quail embryos to understand how cells arrange into a continuous neural tube and what goes wrong when genes linked to human neural tube defects are mutated."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013058^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013058"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding latent fate programming in T cells.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Our immune response to infections and cancer involves amplification of T cells. Each of us has trillions of T cells
column3: with only a handful specific for each infectious agent or cancer cell. What controls the effectiveness of their response is not yet known. In this project
column4: we will use single cell approaches to describe what determines whether a T cell can yield an effective response. These studies will also provide a general framework to assess how fate is controlled in multicellular organisms."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013115^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013115"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Accelerating treatment for epilepsy in children with KIF1A-associated neurological disorders.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Epilepsies are life threatening
column3: where approximately 40% patients do not respond to current medications. Mutations in the KIF1A gene lead to a devastating form of epilepsy where patients die within first 5 years of life. We will use extremely innovative and physiologically relevant models such as stem cells and bioinformatic algorithms to identify novel therapies for KIF1A-related epilepsies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013129^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013129"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A One Health/System Dynamics approach to reducing Clostridioides difficile infection
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Clostridioides difficile infection is a major public health problem. While thought to be acquired in hospitals
column3: evidence is growing that it can be acquired in the community. The bacteria have been found in food
column4: households
column5: farm animals and the environment
column6: but we donât understand what role this plays in human infection. We will use a novel approach using systems modelling to understand how people become exposed to C. difficile and
column7: most importantly
column8: what we can do to control the infection."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013158^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013158"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Polygenic mitochondrial dysfunction in heart failure and neurodegeneration
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mitochondria are the energy producing components of our cells. Genetics influences mitochondrial function
column3: which influences risk for diseases such as heart failure and neurodegeneration. We donât yet fully understand this genetic influence
column4: however we propose that subtle
column5: cumulative genetic (polygenic) differences may be liable. We will test this idea using unique mouse models
column6: and use these findings to identify readily detectable measures for developing heart failure and neurodegeneration."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013180^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013180"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing artificial intelligence
column2: spatial-omics and patient-derived organoids to cure glioblastoma.
column3: Ideas Grants"^"This Proposal will investigate the mechanisms by which tumour cells reprogram healthy non-cancerous cells to support the tumour cellsâ energy demands. Our results will lay the foundations of new anti-cancer approaches that will not only inhibit tumour cell source of energy (metabolism) but also prevent their metabolic compensation via recruitment and reprogramming of surrounding healthy cells."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013189^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013189"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Bioengineered skeletal muscle to discover therapies for age-related muscle weakness
column2: Ideas Grants"^"As we grow older the positive effects of exercise training in muscle are reduced. This project will use 1000s of lab made mini-muscles
column3: which act and function like real human skeletal muscle to understand changes that occur when we get older and how muscle responds to training. By understanding these changes we aim to identify new therapies to treat age-related muscle weakness
column4: so that every Australian can be active and healthy in their older years."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013215^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013215"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding how viruses overcome the nuclear pore complex
column2: the gatekeeper of genomic access
column3: Ideas Grants"^"HIV remains an incurable disease. New ways of treating HIV infection are needed if we are to be ready for emerging strains that are resistant to current treatments. The viral shell
column4: the âcapsidâ
column5: has proven to be a good target for new drugs. We aim to understand how the capsid tricks immune cells into allowing HIV to enter their nuclei where it establishes infection. Understanding how HIV enters the nucleus will not only inform HIV therapies but also virus-inspired gene therapy technologies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013237^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013237"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Overcoming chemoresistance in triple negative breast cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most challenging breast cancer to treat. There is no reliable targeted therapy available and chemotherapy is the standard of care. About 20-25% of patients will become chemoresistant. For these patients
column3: there are few viable treatment options available and their median survival is about 12 months. In this study
column4: we aim to better understand the pathways to chemoresistance and to use a novel paradigm to develop new drugs to circumvent chemoresistance."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013243^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013243"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Top down cortical control of hypothalamic feeding circuits
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Obesity continues to be a significant burden to public health shows no sign of slowing. A central part of the problem is the overconsumption calorically dense
column3: highly palatable and innately rewarding foods. Although genetic evidence shows this overconsumption is driven by our brain
column4: the precise way this occurs remain unknown. In this proposal
column5: we will assess how the brain cortex communicates with the hypothalamus in order to control food intake
column6: food motivation and the development of obesity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013260^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013260"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel
column2: dual-targeted therapeutic approach for reducing diabetes-accelerated atherosclerosis
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Patients with diabetes are in a pro-inflammatory state and many of them develop an aggressive form of heart disease. Blood levels of the pro-inflammatory enzyme myeloperoxidase (MPO) are also elevated in these patients. This project will determine whether treatment with peptides that have anti-diabetic and anti-inflammatory properties plus an MPO inhibitor reduces heart disease in these patients more effectively than the peptides alone or an MPO inhibitor alone."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013278^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013278"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Enhancing mitochondrial energetics to prevent age-associated muscle weakness
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Sarcopenia is a recognized disease of ageing
column3: describing the progressive decline in skeletal muscle mass and strength that occurs from midlife in humans. Recent research suggests that a decline in mitochondrial function
column4: the energy producing cells in our body
column5: precedes the development of sarcopenia. This project will test whether increasing mitochondrial energetics in skeletal muscle with the pharmacological compound BAM15 can prevent sarcopenia in mouse and human models of ageing."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013281^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013281"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding the pathophysiology of Parkinsonâs disease using cellular genomics
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Parkinsonâs disease (PD) is a devastating neurodegenerative condition affecting 1% of Australians aged 60-years and over. Understanding the genetic basis of PD is critical to identifying new drug targets. We will apply powerful methods for measuring gene expression in single cells to identify specific genes that are altered in specific cell types in PD-related brain and gut regions. Our study will shed light on the cell type-specific molecular pathology of PD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013284^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013284"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Transforming fertility treatment
column2: Ideas Grants"^"It is estimated that worldwide 186 million individuals live with infertility. Depending on the cause of infertility
column3: treatment ranges from medications to stimulate ovulation through to more complex procedures
column4: such as in vitro fertilisation (IVF). These fertility treatments have been quite successful; however
column5: they all rely on decades-old medications that promote or suppress hormone activity. We will develop a new set of drugs that target ovarian growth factors to treat or prevent infertility."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013285^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013285"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Bionic-array Directed Gene Electrotransfer for Treating Focal Brain Disorders
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A platform for localized brain gene therapy
column3: âBrain-BaDGEâ
column4: will be developed from proprietary UNSW electric field-focusing technology. This translational program will produce a first-for-human âneedle-likeâ medical device for electrotransfer of therapeutic DNA encoding a neuromodulator targeted to groups of neurons in the brain to suppress epileptic seizures of focal origin. This Brain-BaDGE platform will establish a translational pathway for gene therapies treating localized brain disorders."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013305^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013305"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Precursor neurons on standby fast track neural repair
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Brain and spinal cord injury are devastating events that has a life-long impact on the patientâs life with wide-reaching social and economic effects. This research program uses innovative regeneration models and screening approaches to identify how endogenous cells and molecules can be hoaxed to boost neural regeneration after injury or in disease. The work provides critical insight and hold keys to unlocking strategies for future restorative therapies in the brain or spinal cord."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013323^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013323"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Hospital trajectories for 15 million Australians
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Patient segmentation
column3: which divides a patient population into distinct groups with specific needs and characteristics
column4: underpins a patient-centred approach to health care. We will use hospital records for the population of NSW and deep learning to identify clusters (segments) of patients who share patterns of hospital use
column5: characterise and visualise these
column6: and explore how they change over time. Our novel methods will have application in health service planning and delivery and research."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013349^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013349"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Building the mind: interplay of transcriptional and electrical activities in the self-assembly of cortical circuits in vivo
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The early impact of nature and nurture influences in human brain wiring remains poorly understood due to a lack of ways to study embryonic development in naturalistic live models. We have established advanced new methods in an Australian marsupial that allow
column3: for the first time
column4: mechanistic studies of how genes and electrical activity interact to form precise circuits in the cerebral cortex. These unique opportunities can revolutionise the way we understand brain wiring in health and disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013362^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013362"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Remodelling the ovary to extend female fertility and health
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Female infertility is commonly caused by an inability to release an egg from the ovary
column3: particularly in women who are middle-age or if they have obesity or PCOS. We discovered that these females also have fibrosis in the ovary; excess collagen deposited by cellular stress and inflammation that prevents the egg from being released. This project will identify strategies to combat the detrimental changes in the ovary that cause fibrosis in order to improve female health."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013384^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013384"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Establishment of novel
column2: neuronal-cell based
column3: therapeutic screens for Alzheimerâs disease using patients stem cells
column4: Ideas Grants"^"Alzheimerâs disease is the most common cause of dementia and a major cause of death in Australia. There is no effective treatment for this disease and there is an urgent need to develop treatments to target the cause of the Alzheimerâs disease. This project aims to use human neurons derived from patientâs stem cells to establish a powerful screening platform for the identification of targeted therapeutic drugs to rescue neuron defects to efficiently treat Alzheimerâs disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013404^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013404"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"aSPOC â Commercialisable Aptamer-based Diagnostics for Sepsis Point of Care
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Sepsis - bacterial blood infection - is a common cause of disease in babies and adults. Current diagnostic tests are too slow and often miss the sepsis diagnosis. We have identified blood markers that can improve sepsis diagnosis. Our team have developed a powerful system for making the molecular tools needed to rapidly detect these blood markers. We are working with science and manufacturing experts to make new sepsis tests that can be used easily by frontline staff in hospitals and GP clinics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013421^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013421"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Inhibiting ASC with small molecules for treatment of inflammatory diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"During flu infection inflammation causes significant morbidity there is therefore a need to reduce this inflammation while tackling the viral infection
column3: we have special molecules that have this dual action. We will develop these molecules so they can become future drugs and explore their use in flu models combined with either asthma or obesity as these people are particularly vulnerable to the deadly effects of flu."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013427^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013427"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Do mitochondrial changes underlie insulin resistance induced by inadequate sleep
column2: and can this be prevented by prescribed exercise?
column3: Ideas Grants"^"More than 7.4 million Australians suffer from inadequate sleep. Sleep loss doesn't just make us tired; we have shown it also negatively affects mitochondria ("energy powerhouses") and glucose metabolism (increasing the risk of diabetes). Based on compelling data
column4: this project will discover novel mechanisms responsible for the negative effects of sleep loss and test targeted exercise prescription as a cost-effective strategy to prevent metabolic problems arising from inadequate sleep."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013451^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013451"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"ALPK1 dysfunction: revealing a novel pathogenic pathway in retinal diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Genetic retinal diseases are caused by changes in many different genes and lack effective therapy. This proposal aims to characterise and modulate a newly identified disease pathway in the retina. This holds promise for development of novel approaches to preserve vision in genetic and other forms of blinding retinal degeneration."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013460^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013460"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploiting a novel cell surface biomarker to defeat multiple myeloma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Multiple myeloma is an incurable aggressive cancer of the bone marrow. In Australia
column4: 500 new cases are diagnosed every year with a 5 year survival rate of ~50% and treatment costs exceeding $700
column5: 000 per patient. We have identified a single cell surface protein to be upregulated by ~20% of myeloma patients who are then 3 times more likely to die within 6 years of diagnosis. This study examines a new prognostic tool to rapidly identify poor prognosis patients and new a target to treat them."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013468^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013468"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding the asymptomatic carriage of pathogens and antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in the human gut microbiota
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The rise of microbial antibiotic resistance (AMR) and the lack of novel antibiotic compounds could soon be cancelling the effectiveness of current infectious disease therapies. Understanding and controlling the spread of AMR is a major challenge for public health
column3: but we currently do not understand well if and how healthy people can carry and spread AMR genes. Here
column4: we propose to study AMR dynamics in the gut microbiome of &gt;20
column5: 000 healthy people
column6: linking it with health and prescription records."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013478^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013478"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Identifying rational approaches to enhance the activity of BH3 mimetic drugs in blood cancers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"It is now appreciated that normal cell death prevents cancers from developing; however
column3: this could be undermined in blood cancers (e.g.
column4: leukemias). This is often due to overactivity of BCL2 which allows the cancer cells to persist. Treating patients with a drug blocking BCL2 - venetoclax - is proving highly effective for such blood cancers. However
column5: the disease will often eventually recur: this project seeks to understand why this is and to discover ways by which this can be prevented."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013500^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013500"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"MicroRNA targeting to enhance haematopoietic stem cell function
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The ability to transplant blood stem cells has dramatically improved outcomes for many blood diseases. However
column3: there is a major limitation in the numbers of appropriate blood stem cells available for use. We have identified a gene family that represses the potential of blood stem cells to function after transplantation. Here
column4: we aim to inhibit this gene family to enhance blood stem cell function."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013511^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013511"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The rogue germline: deciphering mechanisms of cancer testis antigen reactivation in cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cancer testis antigens (CTAs) are proteins that are normally expressed in the germline of healthy individuals. During malignant transformation
column3: CTAs become expressed in cancerous tissues
column4: however their role in cancer formation is largely unknown. Given their tissue specificity
column5: CTAs are being actively pursued as targets for cancer immunotherapy. This project aims to unravel the mechanisms of CTA reactivation and interrogate their contribution to cancer formation in vivo."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013538^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013538"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Increasing hematopoietic stem cell niches post transplantation through enhancing bone marrow macrophage resilience and regeneration mechanisms
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bone marrow transplantation
column3: a potential cure for blood cancers and used to enable high dose therapy in treatment resistant cancers
column4: has a high-risk profile preventing treatment progression and high mortality. We will investigate a novel treatment to alleviate transplantation risk by improving the recovery of the recipient's bone marrow environment. It is expected that the efficiency of donor stem cell engraftment will be increased
column5: and reconstitution of blood and immune cells accelerated."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013563^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013563"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Evaluating Systems Change for Health Equity: A Case Study of Australiaâs COVID-19 Policy Response
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will build new resources to evaluate the impact of policy reforms on changes to the underlying societal structures that shape health inequity. Using systems science we will study Australiaâs COVID-19 policy response and the impact it will have on the rules
column3: norms
column4: power dynamics
column5: and resource flows that stratify society and shape peopleâs health. This new evidence will be used to advocate for policy reform that better targets the roots of health inequity in Australia and abroad."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013565^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013565"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"MACHINE LEARNING OF RANDOMISED CONTROLLED TRIALS: A major emerging opportunity to advance precision oncology
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Individual patients can gain very different benefit from the same treatment. Immunotherapy for cancer is an important example of this - some patients have dramatic improvement in survival
column3: whereas many others gain little or no benefit. Currently it is not possible to predict in advance who will benefit and who will not. We will evaluate of a new approach based on machine learning analysis of clinical trials to better distinguish patients who are unlikely to benefit from those who will benefit."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013574^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013574"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reinforcing the cell identity network to improve the function of aged cells
column2: Ideas Grants"^"By 2055
column3: one in four Australians will be aged over 65 and the frequency of age-related disorders will increase. In order to prevent unsustainable burdens for the health system and to reduce human suffering
column4: innovative new therapies are needed to target the underlying causes of ageing. The proposal will provide the basis for new strategies to improve the function of aged cells by directly reinforcing youthful cell identity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013580^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013580"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A dual approach to activate a tumour suppressor for breast cancer therapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cancer is characterised by inactivation of proteins that inhibit cell growth and survival
column3: called tumour suppressors. A rational way to treat cancer is to re-activate the tumour suppressors. Until recently this was not possible. However
column4: we have developed drugs that can do this. Here
column5: we will fully characterise how these drugs function in breast cancer
column6: and use this knowledge to develop new anti-cancer therapies that could have wide reaching applicability for many cancer patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013615^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013615"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Interrogating the therapeutic potential of slow muscle programming in cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Physical activity can improve cancer prognosis
column3: but many patients cannot exercise because of treatment complications. Slow muscle programming could confer exercise-like benefits but its therapeutic potential to improve muscle health in cancer has not been interrogated. These studies will determine whether this strategy can preserve and promote muscle health in different cancer settings. The outcomes will inform development of new therapies for cancer patients throughout the continuum of care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013620^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013620"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Do allergies start with the skin? A novel lipidomic analysis of early life skin to identify âhigh riskâ children and potential targets for preventive interventions
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Eczema and food allergy are common conditions that cause a substantial burden for individuals and families. Impaired skin barrier in early life is believe to be critical in the development of these conditions
column3: and skin lipids (fats) are the âmortarâ that holds the bricks of the skin barrier together. Using a non-invasive technique
column4: we will test if the skin lipids can identify children who will develop eczema and food sensitisation
column5: which may lead to novel preventive strategies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013621^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013621"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Treating Cardiometabolic Disease by Targeting Mitochondrial Defects
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cardiometabolic disease is the leading cause of death and disability in the world. We have discovered that depletion of Coenzyme Q10 (a molecule essential for energy production) occurs in people with pre-diabetes and that boosting CoQ10 is a potential treatment for cardiometabolic disease. Here we seek to understand the underlying cause of CoQ10 depletion and how depletion causes disease. Finally
column3: we will use our newly acquired understanding of the disease process to develop new treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013629^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013629"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Positive allosteric modulation of anti-convulsant G protein-coupled receptor signalling to treat drug-resistant epilepsy.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Epilepsy remains a significant health burden
column3: with current antiseizure medications (ASM) providing inadequate seizure control for &gt;30% of patients. Activation of adenosine A1 receptors
column4: a protein expressed on neurons
column5: can effectively abolish seizures animal models. We will apply multidisciplinary
column6: innovative approaches to develop novel drug leads that can modulate adenosine A1 receptor activity in a more selective and efficacious manner
column7: developing a unique path for ASM discovery."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013631^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013631"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dominant classes of tumour specific antigens in Melanoma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We will explore new classes of antigens that can form targets of vaccines and immunotherapy in melanoma. In particular
column3: we will compare the ability of small protein fragments that are generated via enzymatic modifications or through unusual proteolytic activities to stimulate patient immune responses to those protein fragments that contain cancer specific mutations. We anticipate that the inclusion of a broader variety of antigen classes will boost anti-cancer vaccines."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013641^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013641"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The development and potential of a malaria resistant mosquito for the Southwest Pacific
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Malaria plagues the Southwest Pacific. With no vaccine
column3: resistance to antimalarials growing
column4: vector control is the mainstay in reducing malaria but mosquitoes are adapting to these tools. We are developing a malaria resistant mosquito in the lab with the capability to drive malaria resistant traits through populations. This project will permit the potential of this technology to be explored through population genomics and mathematical modelling to develop simulations of hypothetical releases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013650^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013650"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Towards optimizing diabetes therapies for cardioprotection: Precision approaches for women
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Diabetes is an epidemic disease. A major cause of death in diabetic patients is due to heart damage &amp; women are particularly vulnerable. No heart-specific therapies are available and current guidelines are not gender-targeted. The goal of this project is to understand why women have such high cardiac risk in diabetes
column3: and to identify new treatment opportunities to maximise heart protection for diabetic women."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013757^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013757"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing a real-time machine learning rapid response and risk stratification system for in hospital patients
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We intend to develop and implement a scalable and accurate patient-centred AI system based on the information derived during the whole patient journey for patients in a normal and pandemic setting so as to provide a clinical triage system for patients that match critical resources to patient needs and augment the current rapid response system (RRS) through more accurate and tailored risk predicting."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013783^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013783"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Promoting myelin repair in a refractory environment in vivo.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Many nerve cells in the brain are ensheathed in myelin. Myelin is critical for optimal brain function as it supports nerve cell function and survival. Damage to myelin
column3: as occurs in multiple sclerosis and other neurodegenerative diseases leaves nerve cells vulnerable to degeneration. This proposal aims to identify whether a molecular target we have identified that promotes myelin repair can be optimised and promote myelin repair in a novel and more complex model of brain injury."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2008644^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2008644"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Communicate Study: partnership across the Top End to improve Aboriginal patientsâ experience and outcomes of healthcare
column2: Partnership Projects"^"Effective communication in healthcare improves patient outcomes. Aboriginal language interpreters should be used for around 50% of Aboriginal patients in Northern Territory Top End
column3: but only around 18% of those in need are currently getting access. The Communicate Study
column4: partnering Menzies with health and interpreter services aims to improve cultural safety in healthcare
column5: focusing on improved uptake of Aboriginal interpreters and integration of Aboriginal Heath Practitioners into tertiary care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010289^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010289"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"To Be Born Upon a Pandanus Mat (Yothuw gayatha dhÃ¤walâ guyaÅaânharaw)
column2: Partnership Projects"^"We will establish and evaluate
column3: Australiaâs âBirthing on Countryâ very remote
column4: demonstration site in Galiwinâku
column5: Elcho Island
column6: Northern Territory. We will redesign maternal and infant health services for YolÅu (Aboriginal) families who currently have one of the highest proportions of babies being born too soon (preterm) in Australia (22% versus 7% non-Indigenous Australians). DjÃ¤kamirrsâ (Indigenous doulas) will increase support for women to modify risk factors and reduce preterm birth by 50%."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010493^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010493"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development and evaluation of a Child and Family eHub to improve access
column2: engagement and use of the existing community
column3: social and mental health services system
column4: Partnership Projects"^"Most Australian children with mental health concerns donât get the right care at the right time. With COVID-19 this will only get worse. This project aims to improve access and engagement of existing services to address problems early
column5: especially for disadvantaged families. We will co-develop and test a Child and Family eHub
column6: overlaying existing systems with an easily accessible digital entry point to seek information
column7: connect with services
column8: and provide a care navigator for those most in need."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010866^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2010866"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Optimising the implementation of an evidence-based school program to engage adolescents in muscle-strengthening activities consistent with national guidelines
column2: Partnership Projects"^"School-based physical activity interventions need to be âscaled-upâ to improve population health. The aim of this project is to study the effects of different implementation support models on the scale-up of an evidence-based physical activity program in NSW secondary schools. Expected outcomes include an optimal support model for scaling up school-based health promotion interventions
column3: and population health benefits from participation in resistance training."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011157^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011157"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Promotion of evidence-based physical activity for older adults and people with disabilities by health professionals
column2: Partnership Projects"^"Promotion of physical activity by health services is part of the solution to global inactivity proposed in the WHO Global Action Plan on Physical Activity. Health professionals are an underutilised resource in the global fight against inactivity. This project aims to mobilise and empower Health professionals to encourage and support physical activity among patients by targeting implementation barriers identified at our Partnership health services."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/GNT1078523^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/GNT1078523"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Psychosocial impact of genetic counselling and testing
column2: Research Fellowship"^"Not applicable"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2008937^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2008937"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Healthy Environments And Lives (HEAL) - National Research Network on Human Health and Environmental Change
column2: Special Initiative"^"HEAL aims to strengthen the Australian community and health systemâs resilience to changing environmental conditions
column3: climate change and extreme weather events. This will be achieved by stimulating collaborative research that will improve the current understanding of the interactions between the climate
column4: the natural and built environment and our health. HEAL will lead to more effective policies and measures that will protect and improve the health of the community and reduce inequalities."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011289^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2011289"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Identification of metabolic alterations in cancer cachexia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cachexia is a metabolic disease where tumours cause muscle and fat to waste away. We established a Drosophila (fruit fly) model of cachexia-like wasting
column3: opening up a novel opportunity to use its powerful genetic tools to better understand the genetic basis of cachexia-like wasting. This grant proposes to look at how organs can communicate with each other
column4: and our findings will allow us to find potential new avenues for the development of treatment strategies for cachexia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013881^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013881"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A First-In-Class Tumour Matrix Targeting Approach to Enhance Chemotherapy in Pancreatic Cancer
column2: Development Grants"^"Chemotherapy is the standard-of-care for pancreatic cancer patients. Whilst chemotherapy initially works
column3: it quickly becomes ineffective and patients go on to relapse. One reason for this failure is chemotherapy-induced scarring (fibrosis) in and around the tumour. This scarring blunts the effectiveness of subsequent rounds of treatment. Our preliminary data show that our novel compound can block this scar formation offering a novel stromal targeting approach to improve chemotherapy efficacy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013899^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013899"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a Novel Photo-Angioplasty Device for the Treatment of Occlusive Peripheral Vascular Disease
column2: Development Grants"^"We have designed and developed a new light-activated drug eluting balloon (DEB) angioplasty device termed Lumi-Solve
column3: which targets drug delivery and activation specifically to the surface of a re-narrowed blood vessel
column4: at the time of angioplasty balloon deployment
column5: for the safer and more effective treatment of vascular disease. Our project aims to evaluate Lumi-Solve
column6: in a large animal model with a view to commencing human trials shortly after completion of these studies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013973^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013973"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Preventing reperfusion injury in stroke with an acutely dosed NK1R antagonist prodrug
column2: Development Grants"^"Stroke represents a major clinical and societal burden (on individuals and society) and is the primary cause of adult disability
column3: second-most common cause of dementia
column4: and third-leading cause of death. We will develop a novel and effective intravenous form of a compound known to act beneficially in these clinical settings. This form of administration will act quickly and more effectively with beneficial stroke victim outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014002^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014002"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Building Synthetic DNA Controls for Oxford Nanopore Sequencing.
column2: Development Grants"^"The mutations that cause many cancers are often missed using current sequencing technologies because they are too large and complex. Our partner
column3: Oxford Nanopore Technologies
column4: developed a long-read sequencing method that can detect these complex mutations
column5: but is too inaccurate and unreliable for use in clinical laboratories. We will build synthetic controls that improve the accuracy of long-read sequencing
column6: and enable its use to diagnose mutations that are otherwise missed in cancer patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014063^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014063"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing HCK inhibitor drugs to improve immunotherapy
column2: Development Grants"^"Anti-tumour immune responses are modulated by a cell type called macrophages
column3: which suppress the effects of immunotherapy. We identified a molecule called HCK
column4: which induces macrophages to inhibit the anti-tumour immune response. In collaboration with SYNthesis and the Cancer Therapeutics CRC we will develop inhibitors for HCK. We will test these compounds in preclinical cancer models to identify the most effective combination with immunotherapies to provide the greatest patient benefits."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014079^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014079"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting metabolism to correct fatty liver disease
column2: Development Grants"^"The severe form of fatty liver disease steatohepatitis affects ~40 million people worldwide and has no approved treatment. This project aims to identify new drugs and test them in mouse models to establish proof-of-concept that they safely reverse steatohepatitis. Success of this project will generate new drug candidates for human clinical testing."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014095^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014095"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Lung Ventilation Imaging: A new device to protect the lungs for cancer treatment
column2: Development Grants"^"We will develop a device that gives clinicians insight into how their patients lungs are functioning. The information our technology will provide will allow radiotherapy plans to be shaped to minimise side effects for each individual patient
column3: and allow surgeons to assess suitability for surgery in marginal patients with greater confidence. We will leverage the proven track record of our industry partner in complementary technologies to develop our device into a commercially ready product."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014168^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014168"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a non-invasive mucosal integrity diagnostic and ingestible capsule sampling tool targeting IBD gut health.
column2: Development Grants"^"Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) affects many Australians and is a chronic condition requiring life-long management and intervention. Current technologies to manage the disease include invasive colonoscopy or non-specific lab tests. There is a need for non-invasive methods to improve the health and well-being of people suffering from IBD. We wish to develop a non-invasive diagnostic and ingestible sampling capsule that can determine gut-health and guide treatment for the long-term patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014250^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014250"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing a first-in-class therapeutic for chronic visceral pain using venom derived peptides
column2: Development Grants"^"Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a leading cause of chronic pain
column3: both world-wide and in Australia
column4: but is without treatment. Chronic pain arises from nerve fibres in the colon which fail to "reset" back to normal following inflammation. Targeting these nerve endings with drugs is a key advance in IBS treatment. This project will identify specific voltage-gated sodium channel analogues that act at the level of the colon to numb pain sensing nerve fibres
column5: providing efficacious pain relief in IBS"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014380^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014380"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Retinal Implant with Closed-loop
column2: Multichannel Stimulation to Improve Visual Acuity
column3: Development Grants"^"Previously we developed a retinal implant capable of restoring some vision to a group of patients blinded by the retinal disease
column4: retinitis pigmentosa. However
column5: the level of vision is relatively low. This project will develop a prototype retinal implant that aims to dramatically improve the level of vision provided. This would significantly increase the market of patients that could benefit from the implant."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014388^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014388"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting the Achilleâs heel of multi-drug resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae with drugs that disrupt metal homeostasis
column2: Development Grants"^"Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes sexually transmitted disease gonorrhea. Most gonococcal infections are asymptomatic and can lead to pelvic disease
column3: infertility and increasing risk of HIV co-transmission. Due to the recent emergence of multidrug resistant superbugs
column4: N. gonorrhoeae is now classified as an immediate public-health threat. No vaccine is available. This ideas grant will generate new antibiotics to treat multidrug resistant gonorrhea infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014395^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014395"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel RNA-based therapeutic for liver cancer
column2: Development Grants"^"The outlook for patients with liver cancer is poor. A new form of RNA-based treatment offers promise. An exciting development is the addition of a molecular hook to the RNA
column3: which specifically targets the RNA-drug to the liver. We have modified our drug
column4: miR-7
column5: to make it more effective in the body and also to specifically target the liver. In this project we will evaluate how effective the new drug is and develop some of the essential data needed to progress it to a clinical trial."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014398^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014398"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"RESCUING CONE PHOTORECEPTORS IN RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA WITH LASER-DELIVERED PHOTOBIOMODULATION
column2: Development Grants"^"This proposal develops a new laser to treat the blinding eye condition
column3: retinitis pigmentosa. The low energy laser rescues the light-sensitive film at the back of the eye and preserves central vision preventing complete blindness."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014416^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014416"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a novel topical serine protease inhibitor for tissue repair and inflammatory skin disease
column2: Development Grants"^"Slow tissue repair
column3: excessive scarring and many skin diseases are driven by the bodyâs inappropriate or excessive immune response to the injury or environmental trigger. A key enzyme that causes this excessive response is Granzyme B. We will develop a new drug that can target Granzyme B. We will generate the data to support the first in human trials of the drug at the end of this study to support translation to better treat patients with scarring
column4: fibrosis and inflammatory skin disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014427^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014427"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a potent and fast acting antimalarial that is orally efficacious in vivo
column2: Development Grants"^"Malaria is a devastating disease that causes 420
column3: 000 deaths worldwide annually. Critically malaria parasites have become resistant to nearly all currently used drug classes
column4: and therefore there is an urgent need to develop new therapies. We have identified a highly active antimalarial class with a known mechanism of action and all the prerequisites required to advance this antimalarial class into human clinic trials in partnership with Medicines for Malaria Venture and Janssen Pharmaceuticals."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014512^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014512"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing FXIIa inhibitors as next-generation anticoagulants
column2: Development Grants"^"We have designed a new potential drug to inhibit disease-related blood clotting without interfering with normal clotting processes. The new molecule is promising because it is effective at stopping clotting
column3: but to develop it into a drug we need to generate additional data confirming its safety and stability
column4: then test it in animal models of thrombosis as a precursor to human trials. This project aims to generate these data and to optimise the lead molecule to make it suitable for such trials."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014538^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014538"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a novel blood test that accurately predicts response to checkpoint therapy in cancer patients
column2: Development Grants"^"New cancer therapies that target the patientâs immune system can cure patients whose cancers are resistant to all other therapies. However these new immune targeting treatments are effective in only a minority of patients
column3: can cause significant toxicity and are very expensive. This application will meet the urgent need for a blood test that can accurately predict which patients will respond before therapy is started."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014544^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014544"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel long-acting and orally delivered conotoxin-based peptides with both analgesic efficacy and disease modifying potential.
column2: Development Grants"^"Chronic pain is a common and debilitating condition and there is a significant need for new analgesics to treat this pain. We have designed conotoxin (small peptides from marine cone snail venom) analogues with potent analgesic effects and the objective of this project is the preclinical development of these molecules as novel long-acting treatments of chronic pain."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014584^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2014584"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"c-FIND: Diagnosis of infections in minutes
column2: Development Grants"^"Diagnostic tests dictate treatment algorithms for infectious diseases which has become incredibly complex due antibiotic resistance. The inability to diagnose infections or lengthy delays in diagnosis result in patients being unable to access appropriate
column3: timely or effective treatment. WEHI has been using a gene technology called CRISPR for over a decade and we have adapted this to accurately detect infections in patients within minutes to inform management at the point of care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013798^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013798"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding response and resistance to immunotherapy in immunocompromised patients with cutaneous squamous cell carcinomas
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (CSCC) is common in those with impaired immune systems and these patients have been excluded from the major immunotherapy trials. This research looks at CSCC that has improved or worsened on immunotherapy so we can better understand why some tumours respond and others do not. This will help assess who will benefit from immunotherapy
column3: how we can fight resistance and improve treatment outcomes for vulnerable immunosuppressed patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013800^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013800"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using twin studies to investigate epilepsy aetiology and antiepileptic drug-induced birth defects
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"By measuring and comparing the degree of similarity in a trait or disease between identical and non-identical twins
column3: we can understand how much of the difference in a trait or disease between people is attributable to genes. This project will use twins to study the genetic contributions to epilepsy and to birth defects seen in babies born to mothers taking antiepileptic medications in pregnancy. The results will improve patient management and lead to the development of better treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013809^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013809"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding the genetics and mechanisms of spontaneous coronary artery dissection
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"SCAD occurs in young women as a bleed into the wall of an artery of the heart
column3: resulting in a heart attack. Cause(s) are not known but there is a genetic link in some cases. I plan to: (1) use advanced heart imaging to define differences between heart arteries of affected and unaffected people; (2) use animal models to correlate the observed characteristics (phenotype) and genetics (genotype) of SCAD; (3) sequence DNA from people with SCAD and selected relatives to identify causative genes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013816^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2013816"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Pregnancy in Crohn's and Colitis - Observations
column2: Levels and Outcomes Extension (PICCOLO - X) study
